Review Fluoridation routes, function mechanism and application of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials for various batteries: A review Dedicated to Viji. Weicui Liu a Nanping Deng a ⁎ Gang Wang a Ruru Yu a Xiaoxiao Wang a Bowen Cheng a b Jingge Ju a ⁎ Weimin Kang a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes School of Textile Science and Engineering Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China b School of Material Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China School of Material Science and Engineering Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China School of Material Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract The synthetic route of fluorinated carbon and its schematic mechanism of function in various batteries and the outlook for fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials are summarised in the graphic abstract. With the popularity and widespread applications of electronics, higher demands are being placed on the performance of battery materials. Due to the large difference in electronegativity between fluorine and carbon atoms, doping fluorine atoms in nanocarbon-based materials is considered an effective way to improve the performance of used battery. However, there is still a blank in the systematic review of the mechanism and research progress of fluorine-doped nanostructured carbon materials in various batteries. In this review, the synthetic routes of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based (CF x ) materials under different fluorine sources and the function mechanism of CF x in various batteries are reviewed in detail. Subsequently, judging from the dependence between the structure and electrochemical performance of nanocarbon sources, the progress of CF x based on different dimensions (0D–3D) for primary battery applications is reviewed and the balance between energy density and power density is critically discussed. In addition, the roles of CF x materials in secondary batteries and their current applications in recent years are summarized in detail to illustrate the effect of introducing F atoms. Finally, we envisage the prospect of CF x materials and offer some insights and recommendations to facilitate the further exploration of CF x materials for various high-performance battery applications. Keywords Nanocarbon materials Fluorinated/fluorine-doped effect Function mechanism Various batteries 1 Introduction With the increasing living standards of human and the shortage of traditional fossil energy, a consensus has been reached that renewable energy can replace the non-renewable energy in the future. However, renewable energy sources such as wind, solar and geothermal energy have the drawbacks such as unevenness and discontinuity, which cannot be used continuously. Based on these reasons, researchers are focusing on the development of advanced energy storage, conversion technologies and devices, aiming to use energy storage devices to convert chemical energy into electrical energy for achieving the purpose of storing energy for continuous application. Among various materials, carbon materials are the active substances in battery electrodes, which can provide active sites for ion insertion or de-insertion. In particular, with the vigorous development of nanotechnology, nanocarbon-based materials have also become diverse, including fullerenes, carbon nanotubes, carbon nanofibers, graphene, activated carbons and etc. It is worth noting that nanostructured carbon-based materials are more conducive to shorten ion diffusion pathways [1]. In order to maximize the application value of carbon materials in electrodes, many efforts have been carried out. One of the most effective methods is the doping of fluorine atoms, which can form chemical bonds between fluorine and carbon elements due to the strong oxidation ability and maximum electronegativity of fluorine ions [2]. Thus, fluorinated gases, fluorinated liquids, fluorinated solids and fluorinated plasmas are effective mediums to improve the properties of carbon materials by providing abundant CF bonds to enhance the electrochemical properties of carbon materials. Fluorinated carbon as one of the carbon derivative materials since is very promising it was firstly synthesized by Ruff and Bretschneider in 1934 [3]. CF x materials, particularly those with nanostructures, all exhibit outstanding characteristics such as excellent chemical stability and thermal stability, good thermal conductivity, wide bandgap and super-hydrophobicity due to their abundant CF bonds. [2]. Therefore, CF x materials have drawn widespread attention and have been used in fields such as energy storages (primary batteries and secondary batteries), sensors, solid lubricant, and super-hydrophobicity, etc. [4,5]. The first use of fluorinated carbon materials as active cathode materials in lithium primary batteries (Li/CF x battery) has been proposed by N. Watanabe in 1970s. Subsequently, different types of CF x materials have been employed in various batteries. The fluorination level of carbon materials can be adjusted by selecting of different fluorine source, changing fluorination temperature and time and so on [6]. Due to the difference in electronegativity between C (2.5) and F (4.0) atoms, CF x materials can form different types of CF bonds under the fluorination conditions, including ionic bonds, semi-ionic bonds and covalent bonds [7]. More importantly, the character of CF bonds and the ratio of F to C atoms play a crucial role to optimize the performances of fluorinated carbon materials. For example, when fluorinated carbon materials are used as electrode active materials for energy storage devices, the low specific capacity will be generated by the ionic CF bonds with a small F/C ratio, but the material conductivity will be reduced due to abundant covalent CF bonds with a high F/C ratio. Therefore, optimizing the fluorination conditions is an effective way to improve the performance of fluorinated carbon materials. In addition, the diversity of carbonaceous materials can also provide more possibilities to modulate the electrochemical properties of CF x materials. So far, many studies have been conducted to investigate the synthetic routes and electrochemical properties of CF x materials [7–14]. Unfortunately, a comprehensive description of the function mechanisms for fluorinated carbon materials on various battery systems has not yet been reported until now. This review mainly focuses on the synthesis of CF x materials as well as their effect mechanisms based on electrochemical properties as battery materials as shown in Fig. 1 . It will be carried out from the following three aspects: (1) A brief overview of the preparation of CF x materials for batteries is described which mainly depends on the fluorine source; (2) A summary of the electrochemical behavior and function mechanism of CF x materials is presented in battery systems; (3) Recent advances in the application of CF x in primary and secondary batteries are presented, respectively. The researches and discussion fully demonstrate the effect of the introduction of F atoms in optimizing the electrochemical performance of high-performance energy storage devices. After that, the views and outlook on the problems and development potential of the battery field combined with the above mentioned about CF x materials are also given. We hope to provide an optional direction for future performance improvement of energy storage devices through this systematic review of mechanism effects of CF x materials on electrochemical properties. 2 Preparation methods of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials Up to now, numerous strategies combining carbon and fluorine sources have been explored to prepare fluorinated carbon-based materials based on the performance advantages offered by the fluorinated modification of carbon materials. Depending on the fluorine source, it can be mainly divided into gas fluorination, solid fluoride compounds fluorination, fluorine-containing solutions fluorination and plasma fluorination and so on. For example, Bulusheva et al. [15] compared the effects of different fluorination techniques (gaseous F2, gaseous BrF3 or radio frequency CF4 plasma fluorination) on the thermal stability of fluorinated double-walled carbon nanotubes (DWCNTs). The tested results found that the defluorination process of fluorinated nanotubes mainly depended on the fluorination method. The different fluorination mechanisms of carbon nanotubes resulted in different binding energies between carbon and fluorine atoms, so the fluorinated DWCNTs exhibited different stability. Different fluorination methods and their fluorination mechanisms are briefly described in below content. 2.1 Gas fluorination Gas fluorination as the most common direct fluorination method which mainly refers to the direct contact of carbon materials with fluorine-containing gases (e.g., F2, BrF3, XeF2, ClF3 and etc.). The structures and corresponding properties of the fluorinated carbon-based materials depend on the structures of the carbonaceous raw material as well as the composition of the fluorinated gas, the fluorination temperature and time. Due to the high reactivity of fluorine molecules, pure fluorine gas is the most common effective fluorinating agent. Considering the safety and reactivity of the fluorination process, it is necessary to lower the fluorination temperature or use an inert gas (N2, Ar) to dilute the fluorine gas. Alternatively, the other fluorinated gases can be used to control fluorination process. Because the gaseous mixture of BrF3 and Br2 can fluorinate graphite at room temperature, Yudanov et al. [16] used a gas mixture of BrF3 and Br2 as a fluorinating agent to study the fluorination process of multiwall carbon nanotubes (MWNTs) prepared by the electric arc method. The comparative analysis of fluorinated carbon materials (CF0.3Br0.02) and fluorinated graphite (C2F) was carried out by the X-ray diffraction, infrared spectroscopy and thermogravimetric tests and analysis. The XRD plots of fluorinated carbon materials showed the diffraction reflection characteristics of fluorinated and non-fluorinated graphite layers. In addition, the HRTEM images also presented that only the outer shells of carbon nanotubes were fluorinated, while the inner layers were well graphitized. This was probably because most arc-generated MWNTs can be made up of concentric cylindrical shells while the inner shell remained nonfluorinated. The fluorinating agent influences the level of fluorination and different choices of fluorination methods can produce CF x with similar fluorine content but different morphologies, with significant implications for the properties and applications of nanocarbon materials. Zhang et al. [17] investigated the effect of molecular fluorine (F2) and atomic fluorine (F•) on the fluorination of single-walled carbon nanotubes by thermal decomposition of F2 and XeF2. The fluorinated carbon nanotubes obtained by the two fluorination methods have similar fluorine content, but do not have the same functionalized surface. Some experiments also show that F• produced by thermal decomposition of fluorinating agents are a more controllable fluorination method than that of direct fluorination by F2. To better understand the different fluorination mechanisms, the structure derived from the DFT calculation is shown in Fig. 2 (a–c). The fluorination mechanism with F2 prefers to form fluorine bands with aggregated fluorine atoms on the surface of single-walled carbon nanotubes, while the fluorination mechanism with atomic fluorine results in a uniform distribution of fluorine atoms on the sidewalls of carbon nanotubes. The inhomogeneous distribution of fluorine can be caused by the nanotube fluorination of HF catalyzed by F2 in the pre-fluorinated region. In comparison, the fluorinated carbon nanotubes obtained by F• are isolated and spontaneous, with less surface damage and excellent homogeneity. Therefore, the choice of fluorinating agent is crucial to the various performances and applications of fluorinated carbon-based materials. In addition, Xiao et al. [18] also used pyrolysis of XeF2 under an argon atmosphere at 180 °C for 12 h to fluorinate the prepared graphdiyne (GDY) and changed the degree of fluorination by controlling the mass ratio of XeF2 and GDY. The addition of fluorine atoms disrupts the sp-hybridized carbon atoms of GDY, causing surface defects to trap excitons that make it potentially promising for use in light-emitting devices. As can be seen from the fluorescence spectra at an excitation wavelength of 400 nm, the fluorescence of the fluorinated GDY (FGDY) can be also significantly enhanced when compared to the original GDY. Moreover, the fluorescence intensity increased with the added content of fluorination. Besides, the FGDY-2 had the best photoluminescence performance when the fluorine doping amount was15.2%. The schematic diagram of the FGDY-2 is shown in Fig. 2(d). 2.2 Solid fluoride compounds fluorination Due to the unsafe nature of gaseous fluorination and the importance of precise control of fluorination, atomic F• or molecular F2 can be produced by thermal decomposition of solid fluorinating agents. The gradual release of a certain amount of fluorine during the fluorination process can effectively control the reactivity of the carbon material with fluorine and the degree of fluorination to a certain extent. In particular, this is essential for the chemical and electrochemical properties of fluorinated carbon-based materials. First-transition-row metal fluorides were firstly used in the preparation of fullerenes to obtain controlled and highly fluorinated fullerenes back in 1996. In addition, rare earth metal fluorides, which are elements in the high oxidation state, can easily lose their fluorine atoms under moderate heating [19]. Therefore, TbF4 is considered to be an excellent fluorinating agent for the controlled fluorination of carbon materials. Furthermore, Chilingarov et al. [20] showed that the release of atomic fluorine during the decomposition of solid TbF4 occurred with considerable intensity at relatively low temperatures. The partial pressure value of atomic fluorine was much higher than that corresponding to the equilibrium 2F• ↔ F2, and TbF4 can also be used as a heat generator for atomic fluorine. In contrast to direct fluorination, the thermal decomposition of the TbF4 solid fluorinating agent prevents a highly fluorinated phase and ensures the electrical conductivity of the CF x material. Zhang et al. [21] demonstrated that the fluorination of TbF4 by the thermal decomposition releasing atomic fluorine was a controlled process. The high reactivity and diffusivity of this fluorination process allowed for the continuous addition of fluorine to combine the carbon nanofibers (CNFs) like a more gradual fluorination. Furthermore, the fluorinated phase generated by fluorination using the TbF4 decomposition was always mixed with some residual non-fluorinated CNFs and an excess of fluorine can be effectively avoided. The reasons would lead to a reduction of structural defects such as CF2, CF3 and a reduction in dangling bonds. In terms of electrochemical properties, nano-regions of non-fluorinated carbon atoms must be present. Therefore, it is important to both limit structural defects and cover the total fluorination level (0.03 < F/C ratio < 1.0) to improve the electrochemical performance. In addition, the preparation of CF x by carbonizing fluoropolymers is also a common method. Ming et al. [22] tested a method to prepare CF x by carbonizing PVDF, which was then used as an electrode to surround Fe2O3 nanoparticles to improve electrode conductivity. In this method, PVDF and NMP were used as precursors and solvents, respectively, and CF x layer was used to coat Fe2O3 after drying (120 °C) and carbonizing (600 °C). The presence of fluorinated carbon was analyzed by the EDX and TEM test, etc. The results showed that approximately 12.19% of CF x can be presented in the composite electrode and that the F element was uniformly distributed. The interface region of CF x and Fe3O4 can be observed clearly, and the outer layer of Fe3O4 nanoparticles can be completely covered by amorphous layer. The functionalization of metal oxides with CF x layers can also be extended to improve other electrode materials for advanced energy storage and conversion devices. Lee et al. [23] firstly carbonized monodisperse nanospheres with a copolymer core-silica shell at 800 °C under N2 atmosphere to obtain core–shell (CSC) nanospheres with a carbon core and a silica/carbon composite shell. And then the silica phase of the nanospheres was selectively etched during the thermal decomposition of polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) to synthesize fluorine-doped (FHMC) hollow mesoporous carbon nanospheres for high-performance supercapacitors. The doping of the fluorine atoms increased the polarity and wettability of the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte, which led to an increase in pseudo-capacitance. In addition, Kang’s team prepared F-doped porous carbon nanofibers using PTFE as a fluorine source and a pore-making agent for the carbon nanofibers [24–32]. In detail, the preparation process used polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as the carbon precursor, PTFE as the fluorine source and pore-making agent, and various mixed solutions containing PVP, PTFE and various metal salts (e.g., LaCl3·7H2O, Y(NO3)3 and Co(NO3)2, etc.) were stretched into nanofibers based on the dual action of high voltage and gas pressure by the electro-blown spinning (EBS) equipment. The formed nanofibers were then pre-oxidized in a muffle furnace and carbonized at high temperature in a tube furnace to form active ionic CF and to obtain porous fluorine doped carbon nanofibers with a uniform distribution of metal fluoride. In this case, the PTFE can be decomposed at approximately 600 °C and released a large amount of fluorine-containing gas which reacted with the carbon to form active CF bonds. Because carbon can react readily with fluorine radicals at high temperatures and fluorine pressures, highly fluorinated carbons can be formed. Its application as cathode in energy storage devices exhibited excellent electrochemical performance, thanks to the abundant carbon vacancies generated by F-doping and the abundance of ionic CF and semi-ionic CF bonds, which can significantly improve electron transport capacity and strongly interfacial adsorption for lithium polysulfides (LiPSs). The mechanism of its action in high performance Li-S batteries is shown in Fig. 3 (a–f). Besides, they have also prepared F-doped carbon nanofibers using PAN as carbon precursor by using EBS technology. The method involved immersing the primary fibers in a mixture of the PTFE and Y(NO3)3 for a certain period of time and then obtaining F-doped carbon nanofibers by a pre-oxidation and high temperature carbonization process. The fitted peaks at approximately 685.88 and 688.19 eV were obtained by the XPS analysis corresponding to CF and YF bonds, respectively. The successful introduction of element F in porous carbon nanofibers can greatly reinforce the interfacial interactions through chemical mechanisms, which was very effective in inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites and promoting ion transport, and has promising applications in high-performance Li-S batteries (Fig. 3g and h). 2.3 Fluorine-containing solutions fluorination The fluorination temperature is one of the main factors which determine the properties of fluorinated carbon materials. High fluorine content at high temperatures can increase discharge specific capacity. However, for electrical conductivity it is necessary to limit the penetration of fluorine atoms under the surface of the carbon material to ensure fluorine-free areas. In addition, there is a risk of damaging the carbon-based material at high temperatures. In order to carry out fluorination at low temperatures and under milder conditions, some researchers chose a mild liquid fluorinating agent. For example, Maiti et al. [33] investigated the fluorination reaction of a mild liquid fluorinating agent hexafluor-ophosphoric acid (HPF6) with multiwall carbon nanotube (MWCNT) at different temperatures from room temperature to 150 °C in order to perform the fluorination reaction at a lower temperature and under milder conditions. Subsequently, the generation of CF bonds can be confirmed by FTIR and XPS tests. The covalency of the CF bond also increased with raising temperatures. And the TEM test also clearly showed that effective covalent fluorination using HPF6 did not interfere with the morphology of MWCNT. All in all, when compared to other fluorination techniques, the fluorination ability of HPF6 on MWCNT surfaces was very impressive not only from the point of view of CF x composition, but also in terms of safe handling and mild reaction conditions. Wang et al. [34] prepared fluorinated graphene by dispersing graphene oxide (GO) in hydro-fluoric acid (HF) solution, and the chemical composition, morphology, fluorination mechanism and band gap width of the resulting fluorinated graphene sheets (FGS) were also studied and discussed. The experimental results revealed that the fluorination degree of FGS could be adjusted through varying the reaction temperatures, reaction times and the contents of HF. The fluorination occurs at the initial sp 3 C sites in the GO, i.e., the C sites was attached to the oxygen-containing group. Therefore, a possible fluorination mechanism for FGS is proposed by them as shown in Fig. 4 (a). The six F-containing groups in the FGS can be obtained from the combination of Fig. 4(a,ii–iv), as the oxygen-containing groups were randomly distributed in the prepared GO. The oxygen-containing groups in the GO played a major role in the formation of FGS, and as the tunable C/F atomic ratio value varies, the FGS samples also exhibited different band gap energies, showing potential applications in optoelectronic and photonic devices. The degree of fluorination is closely related to the type of CF bond, which also determines the properties and application performance of CF x materials. Lee et al. [35] synthesized semi-ionically fluorinated graphene (s-FG) by a one-step liquid-phase ClF3 fluorination process. Fig. 4(b) depicts a schematic the experimental steps used to fabricate the s-FG based transport measurement device. The s-FG was synthesized using a single functionalization and intercalation method by adding pure natural graphite to the cold liquid ClF3. The thin s-FG films of several tens of microns in size were successfully obtained based on p-type doped silicon substrates covered with a thermally grown 300 nm thick SiO2 layer, following by reduction with acetone at room temperature. The prepared s-FG films had high insulating properties. However, after the acetone reduction process, the ionic CF bonds can be selectively eliminated and the s-FG regained the high electrical conductivity of graphene. A 109-fold increase in current was observed from 10−13 to 10−4 A at 1 V. The reduced multilayer C2F films exhibited highly p-type doped electrical properties. The fluorination and reduction processes allowed safe and easy non-destructive property control of s-FG membranes. The fluorination and reduction process were used not only for the manufacture of high quality insulators, but also for researches of adatom engineering. Given that fluorination is an effective method for improving the electrochemical capacitive performance of carbon electrodes. The non-porous carbon microsphere electrodes of supercapacitors co-doped with fluorine and nitrogen (CMs) synthesized by Zhou et al. [36]. The study was carried out in a stainless steel autoclave and a dry glove box with flowing N2 using a low temperature solvent heat method with NH4BF4 as the fluorine source and anhydrous CH3CN as the carbon and nitrogen source. The electrochemical characterization showed a significant increase in capacitance due to existence of doping F. The doping of fluorine greatly reduced the charge transfer resistance of the electrode, similar to the enhanced conductivity of fluorination due to the high electronegativity of the fluorine atom. The introduction of fluorine led to an increase in volumetric capacitance of more than 100% when compared to electrodes only doped with nitrogen. And the CM-NF electrodes showed excellent cycling stability with no capacity loss over 10,000 cycles. An et al. [37] prepared 3D fluorinated graphene hydrogels (FGHs) from GO aqueous dispersions by a one-step hydrothermal method at a specific temperature (90, 120, 150 and 180 °C) using hydrofluoric acid (HF) as the fluorine source and used them as binder/additive-free electrode materials for supercapacitors. The chemical and structural characterization of the FGHs showed that the fluorine content could be adjusted by the hydrothermal temperatures. The fluorine content in the FGHs increased with the added hydrothermal temperatures until 150 °C (FGH-150). However, at hydrothermal temperatures of up to 180 °C, a defluorination process occurred, resulting in the absence of fluorine in the FGH-180. Based on the fluorination mechanisms between the GO and HF shown in Fig. 4(c), they can form mono and perfluorinated species, respectively. Isolated fluorine atoms attached to the graphene basal plane tended to form semi-ionic CF bonds with carbon atoms in the sp 2 orbital configuration. Therefore, due to the relatively low fluorine content, the isolated CF bonds of FGH-150 in this study may exhibit a semi-ionic nature. In addition, the X-ray photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) both showed that semi-ionic CF bonds were predominantly presented in the prepared FGHs. The semi-ionic CF bonds in the FGHs promoted ion transport, increased conductivity and provided active sites for faraday reactions and exhibited enhanced specific capacitance and excellent rate capability. 2.4 Plasma fluorination The plasma method is used in reactive ion etching system, where the free radicals generated by fluorine-containing gases which can produce plasma adsorbed on the carbon-based materials to form CF bonds. Sherpa et al. [38] demonstrated the feasibility of plasma fluorination of graphene with sulfur hexafluoride (SF6), which could be a safer alternative to, for example, fluorine and xenon difluoride (XeF2) gas fluorination methods. It was experimentally proven that the fluorine content of the sample could be altered by simply varying the plasma treatment time, and the plasma-assisted fluorination could also modify the electron emission properties of graphene, thus facilitating the application of graphene as an electrode for optoelectronic devices. Their study also confirmed that in addition to the introduction of fluorine sections on the surface of epitaxial graphene (EG), the SF6 plasma treatment of EG introduced structural defects which was because the fact that the ion bombardment in plasma fluorinated EG did not disrupt the framework of sp 2 hybridized carbon atoms [39]. Likewise, Zhang et al. [40] synthesized large-area monolayer fluorinated graphene using SF6 as the fluorine source and controlling the fluorine content in the FG by controlling plasma treatment time. The monolayer graphene was firstly grown on a copper foil and then transferred to a silica substrate, then followed by plasma treatment to vary the fluorine content over a range of reaction times from 10 to 90 s and finally the prepared material could reach a maximum value (∼24.6 atomic % F) with 20 s of plasma treatment. The prepared FG can also provide better performance as a gas-sensitive material for ammonia detection than pristine graphene. The schematic representations of the FG synthesis and device fabrication process are shown in Fig. 5 (a). Plasma fluorination is one of the simplest methods for surface modification, especially due to the capability of dielectric barrier discharges (DBD) to generate non-thermal plasma at atmospheric pressure. For example, Sim et al. [41] used the gases nitrogen (N2), nitrogen trifluoride (NF3), and hydrogen (H2) to fluorinate graphene oxide (GO) by generating plasma through applying the DBD electrodes, where NF3 was used as the F-radical generating gas and H2 catalyzed the decomposition of NF3. Fig. 5(b) shows the synthesis steps of FGO. The DBD plasma can produce a large number of reactive H radicals and electrons which can break the chemical bonds of NF3, producing reactive F radicals to be bound to the GO. Fig. 5(c) gives a photograph of an atmospheric pressure plasma system that can produce up to ∼ 9 kg h−1 of FGO on a large scale when supplied with plasma gas and GO powder. The fluorine atom introduced in GO has been shown to be bound as a CF half-ion with fast electron transfer capability and Faraday pseudo-behavior. Furthermore, it has been elucidated by the DFT calculations that the prepared FGO with CF semi-ionic bonds had a lower adsorption energy, higher electron density and better capacity when compared to the pure GO. Overall, the fluorine source is one of the main factors determining the structures and properties of CF x materials. Gas fluorination is a fast way to prepare fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials and can be produced on a large scale. Molecular fluorine is highly reactive and it is easy to react with carbon materials for obtaining CF x materials with high F/C ratios at certain temperatures. In contrast, atomic fluorine, formed by the thermal decomposition of fluorine-containing gases, allows for controlling fluorination of carbon materials, resulting in a uniform distribution of fluorine atoms and maintaining the intrinsic electronic conductivities of the carbon materials. The release of fluorine atoms can also be obtained by the high-temperature thermal decomposition of solid fluorinating agents, thus precisely controlling the degree of fluorination with carbon materials. However, the reaction rate is usually slow when compared with gas fluorination. The mild fluorine-containing solutions avoid the risks associated with high temperatures and pressures during the fluorination of carbon materials, and these methods are comparatively simple to operate, and are relatively inexpensive cost to prepare them. Nevertheless, liquid fluoridation agents also have some disadvantages, for example, the production of toxic gases that pose a potential hazard to the environment and human health. Plasma fluorination can fluoridate the surface of carbonaceous materials in a relatively short time and does not produce harmful waste, making it an environmentally friendly and efficient novel preparation method. However, the synthesis process of plasma fluorinated carbon materials still requires the application of special plasma equipment, which can still increase the preparation cost. On balance, gas fluorination is one of the most common and promising fluorination method. The method allows for the efficient and large-scale production of CF x materials, which is more in line with the long-term development strategy of industrialization. However, the highly reactive and corrosive nature of F2, which produces toxic and harmful by-products during the treatment process, poses a potential threat to human health and the environment. In order to achieve sustainable development of fluorination one can focus on developing efficient, selective and environmentally friendly catalysts, lowering the temperature and energy consumption of fluorination reactions and reducing the generation of unnecessary by-products. Apart from this, the waste and by-products generated during fluorination process should be managed and disposed of in a rational manner, mainly including some treatment ways such as recycling, reuse and safe disposal. The fluorinated route used for the formation of CF x materials influences their structure and electrochemical properties by regulating the F/C ratio and the type of CF bonds. Highly fluorinated carbon materials can increase the specific capacity of the CF x materials, but also tend to form CF2 and CF3 groups which are ion hindering. Light fluorination also allows the formation of ionic/semi-ionic CF bonds with low bonding energy and retains the sp 2 hybridized carbon in the carbon matrix, which is beneficial for increasing the power density of the cells. For meeting the increasing demand for energy storage in battery systems, in addition to the improved and sustainable development of the fluorination routes mentioned above, some issues such as the high cost of CF x production and the difficulty of producing it on a large scale should be paid much attention and effectively addressed, which will help to advance the commercial application of CF x materials. In addition, there are still some unresolved issues on the mechanism of CF x materials, and further in-depth studies on the properties and reaction mechanisms of the materials also are needed to improve the efficiency of their applications. 3 The function mechanism of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials in the batteries Surface fluorination of carbon materials is an effective way to improve the electrochemical properties and increase the discharge capacity of carbon-based electrodes. To date, more and more fluorination techniques have been applied to introduce fluorine into carbon materials to obtain fluorinated carbon-based materials with the development of fluorine chemistry. The choice of fluorine source, fluorination reaction conditions and carbonaceous raw materials are largely decisive for the properties and applications of CF x materials. The material structure determining the properties of the CF x mainly consists of CF bonds and F/C. Particularly, the combination of the highly electronegative fluorine atom and the low electronegative carbon atom confers different bonding properties to the CF bond, namely ionic, semi-ionic and covalent CF bonds with controllable F/C. Moreover, the energy of the CF bond also increases with the added amount of contained fluorine in the carbon materials [42]. And the theoretical specific capacity of the material will be high as the fluorine content increases, but it also limits the improvement of electronic conductivity of the electrode materials and the formation of the semi-ionic CF bond that promotes the electrochemical performance of CF x as electrode materials [43]. Therefore, reasonable optimization of F/C and adjustment of CF bond type together can better utilize the effect of CF x materials in the battery. The function mechanism of CF x in batteries is mainly manifested in the following aspects: (1) The introduction of fluorine atoms increases the interlayer distance of the carbon material and leads to surface defects. For example, the –CF2 or –CF3 groups are capable of holding ions to increase the specific capacity of the batteries; (2) By modulating the synthetic route of CF x materials, the strength of covalent CF bonds is reduced and electrochemically active CF bonds are formed to construct good ion and electron-conducting networks; (3) During discharge process Li+ may diffuse into the CF x host to form the LiCF ternary compound. The inhibition of LiF formation by stabilizing the LiCF phase is essential to achieve rechargeability of Li/CF x batteries. (4) During battery discharge, CF x material can be converted to LiF, contributing to the formation of a stable SEI layer to inhibit the growth of irregular dendrites; (5) Fluorine atoms can co-dope carbon materials with other heteroatoms to catalyze electrochemical redox reactions, thereby enhancing reaction kinetics; (6) Fluorine-doped carbon materials also have strong physical and chemical adsorption and catalytic conversion capabilities for LiPSs to inhibit their “shuttle effects” and improve sulfur utilization; (7) The regulation of fluorine-containing reagents not only improves the physical and electrochemical properties of the materials, but also increases the capacity by controlling the morphology of the nanocarbon-based materials to generate porous structures which increase the specific surface area and pore volume. As far as the batteries system is concerned, although the introduction of fluorine atoms increases the discharge capacity of carbon materials, the high energy of the CF bonds in CF2 and CF3, which are not easily broken during the discharge process hindering the electrical conductivity of ions. Besides, while pursuing a high fluorine content, the insulation behavior induced by the fluorination process of C-hybridization from sp 2 to sp 3 must also be taken into account. Therefore, controlling the fluorination approach and determining the structure of carbon materials are crucial to the electrochemical performance of CF x cathode materials. Additionally, fluorine-doped carbon materials can induce more structural defects and improve the ability to store ions. Taking the graphite nanosheets (NSs) in Fig. 6 (a) as an example, graphite NSs can develop structural defects and form CF2 functional groups during the fluorination process. The disrupted overall structure of the NSs synthesizes smaller sized nanofragment particles, therefore generating a large number of edge structures to build CF2 type functional groups for capping, which greatly facilitates an increase in the F/C ratio and hence the specific capacity [44]. The semi-ionic CF bond facilitates electron transfer and thus significantly improves the rate performance of the cells. Thus, the modulation of the CF bond from covalent to semi-ionic is particularly important, which can effectively disrupt the bond energy of the CF bond in CF2 and CF3, leading to the conversion of inert CF2 and inactive CF3 to CF and CF2 (Fig. 6c) [45]. The results would improve ion diffusion and electron conduction, resulting in excellent electrochemical properties even at high-rate discharge. The Co-doping of fluorine atoms with other heteroatoms can also extend the bond length of the CF bond and modulate the type of CF bond. The DFT calculations showed that the F, N co-doping lengthens the bond length of the CF bond from 1.382 to 1.41–1.46 Å, which was close to the calculated bond length of a semi-ionic CF bond (Fig. 6b). The introduction of heteroatoms further lowered the energy barrier for electron transportion and exhibited conductive properties [46]. Due to the high dissociation energy of the discharge product LiF, it is difficult to achieve reversibility of primary lithium batteries. During discharge process, the Li+ can diffuse into the CF x to form LiCF ternary compounds (Fig. 6d). This intermediate phase can effectively inhibit the formation of LiF, which made the rechargeability of primary lithium batteries possible [47,48]. In addition to its wide range of applications as a cathode material for primary batteries, the discharge product LiF can also play an important role as a solid electrolyte interface (SEI) in the protection of the anode for rechargeable batteries. The abundance of active semi-ionic C–F and edge CF2 groups on the carbon surface facilitates the production of LiF, resulting in a thin and strong SEI layer which ensures a stable interface during cycling process. The LiF produced by the discharge process can also be partially dissolved in the liquid electrolyte and migrate to the anode side to form a stable SEI layer, thereby inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites (Fig. 7 a) [49]. To address the problem of LiPSs shuttling in Li-S batteries, fluorine doping can enhance the chemical interaction between carbon electrodes and highly polar soluble LiPSs, thereby immobilizing LiPSs and improving the utilization of active materials. Fluorine atoms can also be co-doped with other heteroatoms or metal fluorides in carbonaceous materials to synergistically trap LiPSs and catalyze their conversion to prevent LiPSs diffusion for lithium sulfur battery. The mechanism of adsorption between F-doped porous carbon nanofibers and LiPSs is shown in Fig. 7(b). And the reasonable modulating the fluorine source (PTFE) not only made the physicochemical properties be improved, but also led to the formation of the porous structure to increase the sulfur loading and adsorb LiPSs [27]. In addition, the increased interlayer distance of the carbon material slows down the huge volume expansion during ion insertion/extraction processes and the active sites provided by the fluorine doping enhance ion adsorption and diffusion, resulting in fast kinetics during the processes of charge–discharge. There are several discharge mechanisms in Li/CF x batteries, the difference being mainly in the presence or absence of an intermediate phases or other phases [50–52]. One hypothesis is that LiF is a direct discharge product, in which case the fluorine must diffuse out of the CF x lattice and react with the Li+ from the anode, but requiring a high degree of fluorine diffusivity. Based on the lithium diffusion in CF x with a lower activation barrier, another view is that lithium is embedded in CF x to form an intermediate phase (LiyCF x ), which subsequently decomposes into LiF and C. Besides, in addition to LiF and C, low fluorinated levels of CFL (L ≤ 0.06) have also been identified as being produced during the discharge process. Although the mechanism of the electrochemical reaction in Li/CF x cells has not yet been unified stated, the function mechanism of the CF bond in the cell is still obvious. The electrochemical performance of the cell is closely related to the F/C ratio and detailed type of CF bonds. The introduction of fluorine atoms has worked to excellent advantage in various batteries. Therefore, a review the application of CF x materials in various batteries and further clarify the function mechanism of CF x materials on the electrochemical performance of batteries is presented. 4 Application of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials in various batteries 4.1 Primary batteries Due to the advantages of low self-discharge, constant output voltage wide temperature range and long service life, lithium primary batteries have become the emergency power source for electronic products such as electronic lock, radio frequency identification equipment, artificial heart pacemakers and portable instruments. Fluorinated carbon (CF) with excellent theoretical energy density of 2,180 W h kg−1 and theoretical specific capacity of 865 mA h g−1 is often used as an active material for primary lithium batteries. Such a high theoretical value is equivalent to the conversion of all CF bonds to amorphous carbon during the discharge process, which can be explained according to the following discharge reaction formula (1). The reaction principle is that CF bonds are broken by electrons in the external circuit and then the formed F- combine with Li+ in liquid electrolyte to form LiF. Therefore, the theoretical value is closely related to the x value. (1) C F x + x Li + + x e - → C + x LiF Since the first proposal of graphite fluoride as a primary battery cathode material in 1970s, many methods have been used to prepare this kind of material to improve its electrochemical properties [53–55]. In order to increase the capacity as much as possible, there has been a tendency to increase the level of fluorination of fluorinated carbons. However, the electronic conductivity decreases with increasing fluorine content. The inherent poor electronic conductivity of fluorinated carbon-based materials results in unsatisfactory performance of primary batteries. On the one hand, the actual output capacity of Li/CF x primary cells is usually lower than the theoretical value even at low discharge rates. On the other hand, the low electronic conductivity of CF x electrode materials will lead to disadvantages such as delayed initial potential, poor rate capabilities and heat generation during the operation for Li/CF x batteries [56], limiting their practical application in high power devices [57]. Therefore, balancing the relationship between fluorination content and electronic conductivity is crucial for the electrochemical properties of fluorinated carbon materials. In recent years, a lot of progresses have been made in improving the energy density and power density of lithium primary batteries [45,58–67]. Systematically speaking, there are two main strategies to improve the electrochemical performance of the Li/CF x batteries. On the one hand it is about the preparation of composite electrodes of fluorinated carbon-based materials, such as the introduction of carbon, oxides, polymers and other composite materials or defluorination treatment, but progresses in this area have been limited and rate performance also has not improved significantly [62,64,68–72]. On the other hands it is about the fluorinated carbon-based materials themselves, including the structural design of the carbon source and the optimization of the fluorination method. Fig. 8 briefly lists typical approaches of modified CF x materials in recent years [37,44,61,67,73–76]. All of these reasons will offer the possibility of achieving both high energy density and power density, more suitable for high-current operating conditions [10]. To date, most commercial Li/CF x electrode materials are fluorinated graphite or petroleum coke. The discharge properties of graphite fluoride are related to the CF bond, crystallinity and surface area, which depend not only on the fluorination temperature, but also on the original carbon materials. For instance, the highly crystalline natural graphite produces more ordered graphite fluoride with a smaller d-spacing along the c-axis in comparison to petroleum coke [77,78]. Based on the principle of the discharge behavior of fluorinated carbon-based materials proceeding with the insertion of lithium ions, petroleum coke with a low crystallinity produces relatively less ordered graphite fluoride, resulting in high discharge potentials. Moreover, the low crystalline carbon with large surface area can be easily fluorinated to form C–F layers [79,80]. It is also reported that carbonaceous raw materials with low crystallinity and large specific surface area can be fluorinated at low temperatures or even at room temperature, which will significantly reduce energy consumption. That is the structures and properties of the starting carbon materials are key to obtain high-performance fluorinated carbon-based electrode materials. In particular, with the boom in nanotechnology, more and more researchers are preparing and applying nanostructured carbon materials to replace traditional natural graphite as the original material for fluorinated carbon, which can increase the surface area, thus accordingly significantly improving their electrochemical properties including the rate properties [69,81]. We have briefly summarized many of the key properties of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials used in primary lithium batteries in recent years as shown in Table 1 , which can provide a more visual representation of the progresses made in recent years. New carbon materials at the nanoscale are attracting great interest not only in science but also in the field of nanotechnology applications [91]. More recently, the design and application of nanostructured carbon-based materials has offered the possibility of eliminating the disadvantages inherent in Li/CF x cells. According to the dimensional structure characteristics, nanocarbon sources can be classified as zero-dimensional (0D), one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D) and three-dimensional (3D) materials. They all have their own unique advantages in primary batteries. 4.1.1 0D materials in the primary batteries The 0D carbon-based materials include mainly particles and spheres of small particle size with large specific surface areas and easy dispersibility. The reduction of CF x particle size allows for shortening ion diffusion paths and large specific surface area for providing more active sites, which can achieve better electrochemical properties. Reddy et al. [58]. demonstrated for the first time that the CF x can be made to have small particle size and enhanced physical and electrochemical properties by using high-energy ball milling. However, there is a balance between ball milling conditions for achieving particle size and power density, and too high ball milling speed may be detrimental to the graphite crystal structure and conversely affect the electronic conductivity of the electrodes. Using a homemade device, Wang et al. [88] also prepared a new type of nano-graphite by the method of magnetic grinding, which was then fluorinated at different fluorination temperatures (from 300 to 450 °C), and the preparation process can be seen in Fig. 9 (a). Fig. 9(b–i) show the morphology diagram of different graphites. Since magnetic grinding was less affected by the self-lubricating effect of graphite, it resulted in small particle sizes and generated a large number of active sites on the surface of fluorinated graphite when compared to conventional ball milling methods, which facilitated the rapid transfer or diffusion of Li+ during the charge–discharge processes. As the fluorination temperature increases, the fluorine content also increases, and although this will correspondingly reduce the discharge potential due to the low electrical conductivity, it also induces more F atoms to participate in the discharge reaction, thus increasing the specific discharge capacity. Collectively, the highest specific capacity was obtained for the fluorinated graphite obtained at a fluorination condition of 450 °C (FG-450) compared to other fluorination temperatures. It has a high specific capacity of up to 837.4 mA h g−1 and an energy density of 2004.5 W h kg−1 at 10 mA g−1 (Fig. 9q). It also had an impressive power density of 5460 W kg−1 at 3.6C (Fig. 9r). In addition to the nanometer size of the particles and the large specific surface area, the good electrochemical performance exhibited at FG-450 may also be due to the breakage of the CF bond during the discharge process, forming a continuous LiF shell. After complete discharge, the LiF shell allows the insertion of the lithiated species Li2F+ into the reconstructed carbon lattices by edge or surface diffusions, resulting in additional capacities [61,85,92]. The inherent poor electrical conductivity of CF x also causes voltage delay phenomena and low rates performance, and the introduction of conductive coatings is an effective way to improve the electrochemical performance of CF x . These methods have solved the problem of poor conductivity to some extent. However, low Faraday yields at high rates still exist. Dai et al. [93] demonstrated a new route and model material to minimize voltage delay and achieve high power density in primary lithium batteries. Inspired by the graded structure of pine cones, they also modified pine cone-shaped fluorinated mesocarbon microbead (MF-MCMB) by the “subtraction” under mild hydrothermal conditions. The pinecone shape of the original F-MCMB has a gradient structure and morphology, consisting of nanoparticles of approximately several hundred nanometers in size aggregated into micron clusters. The agglomerates are highly open structures with a porous structure, which is formed due to the release of surface tension during the fluorination process and facilitates the penetration of liquid electrolyte. In contrast, the MF-MCMB spherical particles have clearer edges than the F-MCMB, indicating that higher electronic conductivity after modification can be obtained. Moreover, due to the high temperature and pressure hydrothermal conditions, the particles can be “activated” by some alkali ions and become more porous structure. The porous hierarchical nanostructure can provide more pathways for ion diffusion. The modification also eliminates the inert groups CF2 and CF3 from the surface, creating an effective electron and ion conduction networks. As a result, the MF-MCMB electrode achieved an improved electrochemical performance without damaging the capacity. A voltage delay did not occur until at 5 C, and a discharge specific capacity of 343 mA h g−1 and a maximum power density of 54,600 W kg−1 can be achieved at a high rate of 40 C. Tressaud et al. [73] firstly prepared carbon nanoparticles (CNPs) with low crystallinity and high specific surface area by using the direct electrochemical reduction of molten Li-Na-K carbonates, which were then fluorinated to obtain the fluorinated carbon nanoparticles (F-CNPs) under an atmosphere of fluorine-containing gas and used as cathode active materials of primary lithium battery. Compared to the electrochemical performance of commercial CF x , the open-circuit voltage of F-CNPs was close to 3.8 V (vs. Li+/Li) due to the presence of the non-fluorinated phase and the half-ionic CF bond, which was much higher than that of commercial CF x . Although the non-homogeneous fluorination resulted in no flat discharge plateau, there was no significant potential delay at the start of the discharge curve. Therefore, even though F-CNPs (CF0.43) had lower fluorine content, it can also provide a higher discharge rate. The discharge potential of the F-CNPs (CF0.43) was 0.7–0.9 V higher than that of a commercial CF x and the discharge specific capacity of up to 450 mA h g−1 at a discharge rate of 1 C. The authors for the work also stated that efforts should be made to improve the efficiency of the F-CNPs in order to address the continuous decline of the potential in chronopotentiograms. The 0D carbon materials are widely used in electrodes because of their nano size, large specific surface area and simple preparation process. In order to take full advantage of structures and to improve the overall electrochemical performance of batteries, more and more CF x materials with large aspect ratios and continuous structure are also being explored. 4.1.2 1D materials in the primary batteries The 1D materials mainly include fibers, wires, tubes, strips, etc. with large aspect ratios. The large aspect ratio of 1D materials provides for efficient and continuous electron transportion, and the distances between the nanoscales greatly reduce the ion diffusion length, which can improve the rate performance of the batteries. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have unique structural and electronic properties and they can form three-dimensional interwoven networks based on some designs. Fluorinated carbon nanotubes (F-CNTs) have potential applications as active materials for battery electrodes. 1D nanotubes can satisfy both the need for enhancing inner tubes and shortening ion diffusion lengths. As early as 1998, Hamwi et al. [94] investigated the application of carbon nanotube fluoride synthesized by decomposing acetylene over silica-loaded cobalt catalysts as a cathode material for lithium primary batteries. Although fluorination at room temperature produced a lower fluorine content, the ordered concentric layers facilitated the diffusion of Li+. Some researchers have been concentrating on increasing the intrinsic conductivity of the CF x cathode to minimize the drawbacks of low power density and Faraday yields. The concept of sparing some carbon atoms from fluorination can be formed so that the conductive part remained inside the insulating fluorinated carbon lattice is called “sub-fluorination”. These non-fluorinated carbon atoms can form a conductive path to ensure the excellent conductivity of the electrode. The related work was firstly reported by Yazami et al. [95] who chose carbon nanofibers (CNFs) as the starting carbon-based materials in order to increase the intrinsic conductivity of the CF x cathode material and to achieve an extended discharge current range, and compared it with the coke under precisely controlling fluorination conditions. The controlled fluorination of CNFs allowed the coexistence of fluorinated and non-fluorinated regions at the nanoscale. On the one hand, with increasing fluorination temperature, the additional fluorine insertion led to an increased density of defects including cracks in the carbon layer, openings at the ends of the CNFs and lattice distortions, which will provide additional and easy pathways for the diffusion of lithium ions within the core of the fluorinated structure and into the electrochemically active C–F sites. On the other hand, a small number of non-fluorinated regions favored high electron flow and thus enhanced conductivity. The resulting fluorinated CNFs therefore achieve current densities of up to 6 C and power densities greater than 8000 W kg−1 as the cathode material for primary lithium batteries. On this basis, Yue et al. [84] systematically investigated the synthesis process and electrochemical properties of FCNTs, showing that fluorine atoms were inserted into the outer part of the carbon nanotubes, while the inner part was not. The non-fluorinated sp 2 C atoms can be observed even at a fluorination temperature of 430 °C. The hybridization in the core of non-fluorinated sp 2 carbon nanotubes in fluorinated carbon nanotubes can be acted as an easy path for electrons transportion, contributing to high discharge capacity and good rate performance. Therefore, the cells assembled by the FCNTs (CF0.75) obtained at a low fluorination temperature of 400 °C also had superior energy density of 1147 W h kg−1 and power density of 8998 W kg−1 at a current density of 4 A g−1. The large number of inert CF2 and CF3 groups and dangling bonds are thought to be structural defects which can prevent the diffusion of Li+. Zhang et al. [96] prepared fluorinated carbon nanofibers (FCNFs) by applying the direct fluorination of F2 gas and controlling fluorination by TbF4 decomposition, respectively. And they also discussed their electrochemical properties associated with the fluorination mode. For use as lithium primary battery cathode materials, the controlled FCNFs obtained higher electrochemical properties due to the superior diffusion and reactivity of atomic F over molecular F, which greatly reduced the electrochemically inert CF2 and CF3 groups and improved the electrochemical kinetics. Notably, the relatively low degree of fluorination limited the capacity, while deeply fluorinated carbon nanotubes exhibit the stable potential and Faraday yield at low discharge rate. Li et al. [75] further investigated the rate performance of deeply fluorinated carbon nanotubes with different diameters and explored the detailed discharge mechanism. The deeply F-MWCNTs of different diameters with the molar ratio of fluorine to carbon close to 1 could be obtained in the fluorine/nitrogen gas. The 1D F-MWCNTs can form a continuous network, which was partially converted to conductive MWCNTs during discharge process and the remaining fluorinated part was in close contact on the nanoscale. This distribution facilitates the flow of electrons within the F-MWCNTs and ensures high power density. It should be noted that the smaller the diameter of the F-MWCNT was, the more likely it was to be encapsulated by the discharge product LiF and easily blocked by LiF due to the small voids between the F-MWCNTs, leading to increasing resistance and preventing the diffusion of Li+. Therefore, a larger diameter F-MWCNTs network exhibited the high Faraday yield and rate performance due to the larger pore volume. The F-MWCNTs with an average diameter larger than 50 nm can support discharge at a rate of 5 C with a power density of up to 7114.1 W kg−1 and an energy density of 1923 W h kg−1. Due to the insulating nature of the fluorinated part, the nano-regions of non-fluorinated carbon atoms must be presented to ensure the electronic conductivity of the battery during discharge process. Ahmad et al. [83] obtained fluorinated carbon nanofibers by means of static fluorination. As static fluorination allowed precise control over the addition of fluorine, a specific distribution of fluorinated and non-fluorinated regions on carbon nanofibers can be achieved to ensure flux of electrons in the non-fluorinated regions during electrochemical discharge and towards the fluorinated regions of the insulation. The energy density and Faraday yield of this sample were as high as 1780 W h kg−1 and 98%, respectively. This was mainly attributed to the diffusion of fluorine ions obtained by the reduction of CF bonds due to electron diffusion, as well as the diffusion of lithium ions during discharge process. Thus, the good electronic conductivity of the non-fluorinated region ensured a satisfactory electrochemical performance of the Li/CF x cell. Fluorinating only the outer walls of the CNTs, while retaining the mechanical and electronic properties of the inner CNTs, is a significant advantage of using molecular fluorine F2 [15,84,97]. Based on these reasons, Ahmad et al. [85] also obtained additional capacity for primary lithium batteries by direct fluorination of few walled carbon nanotubes (FWCNTs) with F2 gas. The material was characterized in depth by TEM, Raman and solid-state 13C and 19F NMR to explain the additional capacity. This mainly was due to the enhanced effect of the central tube and the short ion diffusion distance. Additional insertion of lithiated material after electrochemical defluorination was also allowed. It may be that the insertion was between the initial non-fluorinated tube as an enhanced tube and the carbon structure reconstructed by electrochemical defluorination, or the lithiated material may be inserted between the tubes in the bundle. It is worth noting that the extra capacity depended on the number of concentric tubes and an optimum number of tubes may exist to obtain the extra capacity. As a result, the prepared FWCNTs with a relatively low fluorine content (F/C = 0.37) exhibited a high discharge capacity of 900 mA h g−1 exceeding the theoretical value at a current density of 10 mA g−1 when used in primary lithium batteries. They also had an energy density of up to 2565 W h kg−1 with a Faraday yield of 172%. The concept of enhanced effects holds promise for extension to other carbon nanomaterials. Graphitization has been reported to be effective in reducing defects and improving the structural crystallinity of carbon nanotubes. Based on this, Li et al. [87] explored the effect of graphitization on fluorinated carbon nanotubes (FCNTs) to show the role of graphitization on the degree of fluorination of CNTs and the electrochemical properties of FCNTs. The structural stability of carbon nanotubes under high temperature fluorine gas can be greatly improved by graphitization process. At the same fluorination temperature, the fluorinated graphitized CNTs (FGCNT-x) had better electrochemical performance than FCNT-x due to the lower F/C ratio and weaker CF bonds of FGCNT-x prepared from graphitized CNTs than those of FCNT-x prepared from ordinary CNTs. In comparison, the FGCNT-0.81 used as cathode materials for Li/CF x battery can reach the maximum energy density of 2006.6 W h kg−1. What’s more, the specific capacity of FGCNT-0.81 was as high as 798.8 mA h g−1, which was almost the same as the theoretical capacity (790 mA h g−1). They further applied FGCNT-x to Na/CF x primary cells, where the discharge mechanism was similar to that of Li/CF x cells as CF x + xNa++xe−→C + xNaF. Probably due to the greater Na+ (1.02 Å) than Li+ (0.76 Å). A maximum energy density of 1733.4 W h kg−1 can be achieved for Na/CF x cells assembled with the FGCNT-0.81, demonstrating great potential in low power applications. Furthermore, Peng et al. [90] achieved the unzipping of single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNT) to obtain fluorinated graphene nanoribbons (F-GNRs) by adjusting the fluorination conditions at more than 300 °C (Fig. 10 a–e). The DFT calculations showed that the fluorine atoms adsorbed on the exterior of SWCNT were in zigzag paths, thus triggering the spontaneous process of SWCNT unzipping. The high fluorination and discharge plateau of F-GNRs were made possible by the abundant edges (–CF2) and the disrupted periodic structure. Finally, the F-GNRs obtained by unzipping SWCNT at 350 °C exhibited extremely high energy density of 2738.45 W h kg−1, which can exceed the theoretical energy densities of typical lithium primary batteries and even other lithium metal batteries (Fig. 10f and g), demonstrating a promising application in the field of ultra-high energy density power supplies. 4.1.3 2D materials in the primary batteries The 2D materials are generally defined as layered materials, mainly involving graphene, carbon nanosheets and carbon nanodiscs with extraordinary properties such as ultra-high theoretical specific surface area, excellent charge carrier mobility and high thermal conductivity. 2D graphene materials have attracted much attention for their superior mechanical strengths and electrical conductivities. Due to the special properties and performance of graphene, the carbon nanomaterial has been intensively studied by many researchers [11]. Among the various functionalization studies of graphene materials, fluorination is one of the most effective methods [41]. Fluorinated graphene (FG) is thought to be the basic two-dimensional structural element of graphite fluoride first synthesized by Ruff et al. The surface area of fluorinated graphene layers and interlayer spacing are the main factors affecting the discharge potential during CF x reduction [73], which has a high potential of up to 4.57 V in Li/CF x cells calculated from thermodynamic data at 25 °C. [7]. For example, Damien et al. [59] synthesized a low degree of fluorinated FG by the chemical exfoliation method, and the prepared electrode can achieve enhanced energy density, power density and Faraday yield in a single step in a lithium primary battery. The low fluorination maintained the graphitic nature of the raw material. Despite the reduced fluorine content, the capacity of the FC electrode can be increased by approximately 40% compared to the original fluorinated graphite polymer ((CF0.25) n ) electrode. At the same current density of 10 mA g−1, the FG electrode had a discharge specific capacity of 767 mA h g−1, which was comparable to the theoretical specific capacity of the pure (CF0.25) n for a lithium primary battery with a specific capacity of only 550 mA h g−1. According to the discharge mechanism firstly proposed by Wittingham, a graphite intercalation compound (GIC) consisting of fluorinated graphite and solvated Li+ in a Li/CF x cell would hinder the theoretical open-circuit voltage (OCV). The nanoscale design of FG electrode materials can greatly improve the diffusion kinetics of solvated Li+ by reducing the thickness of the GIC. The thin GIC layer formed on the fluorinated graphene-based electrode after liquid-phase chemical exfoliation combined with hydrazine reduction can effectively facilitated the rapid transport of solvated Li+ and consumes F atoms, as shown in Fig. 11 (a). In addition, the F atoms from the FG with large specific surface area are easily accessible to the solvated Li+, leading to an increased energy density and Faraday yield in the prepared electrode. The introduction of fluorine atoms can cause defects on the surface of carbon materials, such as CF2 and CF3 groups capable of holding lithium ions. Therefore, the energy density of the battery enhances with increasing fluorine content. However, these groups are electrochemically inert and can even hinder the diffusion of lithium ions, thus reducing the electrochemical kinetics. Moreover, the presence of strong C–F covalent bonds also caused a decrease in the electronic conductivity of the fluorinated carbon-based material, resulting in electrode polarization. Sun et al. [98] obtained the FG nanosheets by using the solvent thermal exfoliation of fluorinated graphite using the chemically inert and low boiling organic solvents acetonitrile and chloroform, respectively (Fig. 11b). The disordered edges of the FG and the irregularity of the few layers folded along the stacking direction testify to its high yield. It was shown by FT-IR and XPS analysis that the FG nanosheets (FG-2) exfoliated using chloroform induced the conversion of covalent CF bonds to semi-ionic CF bonds. The transformation of CF bonds may be due to the formation of hydrogen bonds between the chloroform molecule and the F atom of F-graphite, causing the electron cloud of the CF bond to move toward the F atom. FG-2 with semi-ionic CF bonds shows higher discharge voltage and excellent rate performance. Based on the increased interlayer space and large specific surface area, Li+ can be diffused into the FG interlayer, FG-2 shows a discharge specific capacity of 775 mA h g−1 at a current density of 0.05 C, which was about 95%–96% of the theoretical specific capacity, yet F-graphite was only 87% (Fig. 11c). These nanostructures facilitated lithium ions diffusion and electron migration even at high discharge rates. The prepared FG-2 exhibited a specific capacity of up to 520 mA h g−1 at 1 C, which was five times that of F-graphite, and showing the highest power density of 4038 W kg−1 at 3 C among various samples (Fig. 11d). In addition, Xu et al. [99] also prepared F-graphene nanosheets by liquid exfoliation of F-graphite using a 2-propanol/water solution and used them as the cathode material for primary lithium batteries. The average discharge potential and capacity of F-graphene nanosheets were higher than those of F-graphite, which can be attributed to the reduction of CF2 and CF3 surface groups. And the thin 2D nanosheet structure of F-graphene can facilitate the rapid diffusion of Li+ and provide more contact surface area between Li+ and CF bonds. In order to limit the formation of non-electrochemically active CF2 and CF3 groups, the concept of “sub-fluorination” has been introduced in some carbon-based materials to achieve high power density. In particular, sub-fluorination is very effective way for various nanostructured carbon materials, and precise controlling of fluorination also allowed for a variety of possible distributions of fluorinated and non-fluorinated regions. However, the sub-fluorination treatment using molecular F2 tended to form CF2 and CF3 groups and suspension bonds. In addition, electrochemical discharges also lead to structural disorder during the conversion of CF x to carbon and LiF, and the reconstruction of carbon lattices with minimal defects was advantageous, so the selection of nanocarbon-based materials for fluorination was crucial. Therefore, Ahmad et al. [61] used TbF4 as a solid fluorinating agent to control the reactivity of fluorine atoms with carbon nanodiscs (CNDs) and the level of fluorination to reduce structural defects. The slow kinetics of the thermal decomposition of TbF4 allowed for the continuous addition of fluorine to CNDs and progressive fluorination when compared to the direct sub-fluorination of F2. The atomic fluorine produced by the thermal decomposition of TbF4 was more reactive and well distributed than molecular fluorine, which facilitates the formation of the (CF)n phase. It was worth noting that the controlled fluorination of the fluorinated CND also gave additional discharge capacity. Under controlled fluorination at 500 °C (C-500 with F/C = 0.72) and 550 °C (C-550 with F/C = 0.95), the primary lithium batteries with fluorinated CNDs as cathode materials achieved experimental capacities of 955 and 978 mA h g−1 at a current density of 10 mA g−1 in EC/PC/3DMC LiPF6 1 M electrolyte, respectively, which exceeded the theoretical discharge capacity. The phenomenon implies that the dimensionality of the carbon source also plays a key role. They concluded that the extra capacity stemmed from the insertion of the lithiated substance Li2F+ into the newly formed carbon lattice by electrochemical defluorination. Fig. 11(e) shows the electrochemical discharge mechanism and the phenomenon generating the extra capacity. The LiF layer facilitated its decomposition to form Li2F+ substances. And the thicker the LiF layer, the greater the insertion and additional capacity of the lithiated substances. Considering the greater solubility of LiF in EC/PC/3DMC LiPF6 1 M electrolyte when compared with PC LiClO4 electrolyte, the Li/CF x battery assembled with the PC LiClO4 electrolyte using fluorinated CND (C-550) as anode reached a discharge specific capacity of 1180 mA h g−1 at a current density of 10 mA g−1 (Fig. 11f). The additional capacity also resulted from the reinforcement effect of the central disc and the small number of structural defects CF2 and CF3. Yang et al. [44] synthesized fluorinated graphene nanosheets (NSs) by using the static fluorination at different temperatures (250–400 °C). An F/C of up to 1.34 can be achieved through changing the temperature. The temperature tuning also allowed the introduction of edge defects, –CF2, –CF3 functional groups as well as some nonfluorinated regions into the graphene NSs, resulting in covalent/semi-covalent/semi-ionic bonds of the hybridization type. The graphene NSs CF x -400 optimized at 400 °C provided the highest specific capacity of 921 mA h g−1 and obtained an energy density of 2210 W h kg−1 at a current density of 10 mA g−1. The soft packed batteries were further tested and reached specific energies of 1021.5 and 1115 W h kg−1 after discharge at room temperature and 60 °C, respectively, far exceeding commercially available primary lithium batteries, which was significant for their practical applications. 4.1.4 3D materials in the primary batteries 3D materials are generally activated carbon, hydrogel and mesoporous carbon with a porous structure, etc. A number of fluorinated nanocarbon materials have already been used as active materials of cell electrodes. However, in comparison, the specific surface area of non-porous materials is relatively low than that of porous materials. In addition, high temperatures and the degree of fluorination can also damage the pore structure of porous materials and affect the high and multiplicity performance of anode electrode materials. In order to prevent pore collapse, the development and application of porous carbon-based materials is not a less effective method. Fulvio et al. [82] used low temperature fluorination of soft template and activated them to obtain mesoporous carbons. They can be fluorinated at lower temperatures than graphitic carbon because they have a graded pore structure including micro- and mesopores. In addition, the Li/CF x cells prepared from fluorinated activated mesoporous carbon (MA-CF0.55) also exhibited excellent rate performance due to their micro- and mesoporous structure and high discharge potential. Compared to commercial fluorinated carbon electrodes containing similar fluorine content, the cells assembled from the MA-CF0.55 had much higher power and energy densities. Especially at large discharge rates of 5 C, where the power and energy densities were 52.8% and 63.9%, respectively. Graphene hydrogels have a 3D porous structure, large specific surface area and abundant heteroatom doping, which could ensure sufficient contact between graphene and fluorine gas during the fluorination process, resulting in a homogeneous fluorination reaction and a high degree of fluorination. Bi et al. [86] designed and prepared FG consisting of multilayer graphene sheets with a 3D interconnected structure by using the direct fluorination using N, O co-doped graphene aerogels as the carbon source. At different fluorination temperatures, fluorine atoms can enter the graphene skeleton through substitution processes containing N, O groups and the addition of C–C bonds, subsequently forming fluorides with different fluorine contents. Overall, the assembled FG-300 cathode material prepared at 300 °C had the optimum electrochemical performance, yielding a discharge specific capacity of 632 mA h g−1 and an energy density of 1485 W h kg−1. Given the high cost and production instability of nanostructured carbon materials hindering their practical application in lithium primary batteries, Jiang et al. [89] prepared fluorinated ketjenblack (FKB) with high fluorine content by gas-phase fluorination, which can be seen from the SEM image in the Fig. 12 (a and b) as a fluffy 3D structure made of nanoparticles stacked. The fluffy structure can increase the contact area between the electrode material and the electrolyte, narrow the diffusion path of lithium ions and reduce the internal resistance of the cell. The FKB prepared at 520 °C (KFB-3) exhibited excellent energy density (1344 W h kg−1) and power density (27493 W kg−1) at 20 C due to the amorphous carbon structure and relatively suitable semi-ionic CF bonds and covalent CF bonds, and showed outstanding rate performance without reducing the energy density (Fig. 12c). Li et al. [66] used Cr metal–organic frameworks (CM) derived porous carbons as the sources of CF x to prepare cathodeof Li/CF x batteries. The CM was firstly carbonized in nitrogen gas and then fluorinated at different temperature (250, 300 and 350 °C) in a mixture of fluorine and nitrogen to become F-CM (F-CM-250, F-CM-300 and F-CM-350; Fig. 12d). It can be seen from the SEM images as presented in Fig. 12(e–h), the F-CM not only maintained the structure of the metal organic framework intact, but also produced a large number of nanopores under the etching effect of the metal oxide during the fluorination process. The final results showed that the F-CM-350 possessed a higher specific energy of 2110.7 W h kg−1 and specific capacity of 850.3 mA h g−1 at a current density of 10 mA g−1 (Fig. 12i and j) and low volume expansion (no more than 12%) owning to the special structure of MOF, which can effectively solve the problem of large volumetric change in the assembled Li/CF x batteries. The rich structure and low cost of MOF offered the possibility of designing and preparing multifunctional fluorinated carbons. The simultaneous achievement of power density and energy density of CF x cathode material is a challenge which has plagued many researchers and this also has limited its wide application. For example, Luo et al. [67] prepared flower-like porous fluorinated graphene microspheres (FGS-1.03) composed of nanosheets with uniform distribution of fluorine atoms and high F/C ratio by using 3D porous GSs as the raw material. The prepared FGS-1.03 had achieved superb energy density and power density in both coin-type cell and pouch-type battery applications. They also analyzed the reasons for the improved electrochemical performance from four aspects: Firstly, the high fluorine content ensured excellent energy density and outstanding specific capacity. Secondly, the 3D porous structure exposed more active surfaces and shortened the diffusion distance of lithium ions and electrons. Thirdly, the intermediate layer facilitated the rapid insertion of lithium ions and maintains structural stability.
