Fourthly, the large amount of sp 2 carbon and active CF bonds and a small amount of inert CF2 bonds formed an electron-conducting network which can ensured the complete release of discharge capacity. As a result, the FGS-1.03 cathode material can achieve an unprecedented power density of 71,180.9 W kg−1 and a high energy density of 830.7 W h kg−1 at a high current density of 50 C when used in a coin-type cell. Moreover, a ground-breaking power density of 12,451.2 W kg−1 at 20 C was also demonstrated in the pouch-type battery. It was found that the prepared FGS-1.03 had well structural stability and uniform LiF formation at different discharge depths by the in-situ XPS, EIS and SEM studies. The growth and accumulation of LiF particles on the edges of the lamellae resulting from the electrochemical process of fluorinated carbon de-fluoridation may result in partial spalling of the layered carbon and loss of electrical contact with some partially defluorinated portions of the electrode, bringing the inactivation of the CF bond and reduced Faraday yields. It is therefore necessary to prepare large cavities of fluorinated carbon to contain the LiF and avoid exfoliation. Mar et al. [63] used the versatility of fluorination to design and prepare the accordion-like exfoliated graphite (EXF) composed of graphene sheets. Fluorinated EXF exhibited an unusual double CF bond, i.e., a weak covalent bond and a usual covalent bond. The formed double CF bond may have been present in the original graphite sample or the curvature of the exfoliated graphene sheets may have prevented the overlap of carbon and fluorine atomic orbitals and weakened the covalent nature of the carbon. The formed bond allowed for an increase in the discharge potential at the start of the electrochemical process. In addition to this, the gaps between the multiple layers of EXF can accommodate LiF and allow the LiF particles to grow in the large open pores. With the growing demand in the energy storage market, the high cost and limited reserves of lithium resources have also gained widespread attention of the public. New types of energy storage systems based on a wider range of elements are still needed. Sodium and potassium, which are abundant elements on earth and chemically similar to lithium, are considered to be the most promising electrode materials for low-cost batteries. Luo et al. [100] prepared three types of 3D porous accordion-like fluorinated graphite nanosheets (FGNSs) with different F/C ratios from graphene nanosheets by freeze-drying and gas fluorination, and used them as cathode materials for sodium and potassium primary cells (Fig. 13 a–d). In order to obtain excellent energy density and discharge rate at the same time, the fluorine content in FGNSs-x can be regulated by controlling the fluorination temperature. The prepared FGNSs-1.0 prepared at 500 °C had not only high F/C (1.0) but also more CC bonds (7.14%), exhibiting unprecedented energy density and power density. A schematic comparison of the electron–ion pathways in the discharge process of FGNSs-1.0 and conventional fluorinated carbon (C/F = 1), the obtained FGNSs-1.0 showed the marked advantages (Fig. 13e and f). Firstly, the nanostructure increased the specific surface area and ensured that the active material can be fully utilized. Then, the 3D porous structure can also provide an abundance of channels and accommodate the large volume expansion of the active material during the discharge process. Finally, the formation of sp 2 CC bonds and the low number of CF2 inert groups reduced barriers to electron transfer and ion transport, building an effective conducting network. Thus, the maximum energy densities of 1960.5 and 2144.6 W h kg−1 and the maximum power densities of 7076.8 and 6227.4 W kg−1 can be obtained in the sodium and potassium primary cells, respectively (Fig. 13h–j). In addition, the FGNSs-1.0 cathodes also exhibited excellent electrochemical performance in pouch-type cells. At a discharge current density of 100 mA g−1, the sodium and potassium pouch-type cells had a discharge capacity of 738.8 and 797.3 mA h g−1 and energy densities of 1575.8 and 1879.0 W h kg−1, respectively (Fig. 13k and l). All of these can provide a viable candidate for commercialization of primary cells. 4.2 Secondary batteries With the highest energy density of any primary battery, Li/CF x batteries remain an important power source in medical devices and the military [101]. Although numerous strategies have been successfully employed to increase the diffusion of lithium ions, fluoride ions, and electrons to improve the electrochemical performance of fluorocarbon-based materials in lithium primary batteries. However, primary batteries still have inherent disadvantages such as non-rechargeability increasing costs and placing a burden on battery recycling, which have a negative impact on the environment. In view of these considerations, lithium-based secondary batteries have been widely developed as an advanced energy storage system and are successfully used in electric vehicles and portable electronic devices. However, lithium resources are scarce and unevenly distributed on the planet, so it is imperative that novel type batteries such as sodium and potassium batteries with comparable performance are developed using the abundant elements, and various types of batteries can form complementary advantages [102]. Successively, the reversibility of CF x cathode materials in sodium, potassium and lithium batteries was also demonstrated. For example, Liu et al. [103] proved for the first time that the CF x materials as cathode can be applied to rechargeable sodium batteries. The CF x cathodes was prepared with the same method to use in Li/CF x battery and Na/CF x battery for comparison. The related experiments further also proved the irreversible reaction of CF x with lithium, but the carbon in Na/CF x batteries can decompose the discharge product of NaF at room temperature due to the lower crystallize size of NaF than that of LiF. In addition, the NaF also had lower bond and dissociation energy when compared with LiF. Thus, the electrochemical reaction between CF x and Na was highly reversible. And the reversible electrochemical reaction mechanism of CF x and Na was as follow. (2) C F x + x Na + + x e - ↔ x N a F c r y s t a l l i n e + C However, it can be concluded that the rechargeable Na/CF x batteries possessed the shortcoming of high voltage-polarization between charge and discharge and produced unstable cycle property. Thus, the assembled Na/CF x batteries need to be further improved for practical application in the future. Next, we will review the progress of CF x for electrode materials or interlayer materials by different types of secondary batteries. 4.2.1 Rechargeable sodium batteries CF x was firstly selected as the cathode material for primary lithium batteries. But with the popularization of electronic products, there was a demand for rechargeable energy storage devices. Inspired by the effect of catalyst on charging and discharging processes, Liu et al. [104] tried to use fluorinated multi-walled carbon nanotubes (F-MWCNTs) instead of carbon to catalyze the decomposition of NaF discharge products in the Na/CF x cells. They also applied CF x , graphene nanosheets and FeF3 (CGF) as cathodes to Na/CF x batteries for further improving the electrochemical performance of the cells. The results showed that the cathode active materials of F-MWCNTs revealed a bidirectional promoting effect on the electrochemical activity of the discharge and charge processes for the assembled Na/F-MWCNTs battery. Comparatively speaking, there was a small voltage gap in the discharge and charge curves for Na/CGF cell, indicating that the CGF cathode possessed better electrocatalytic activity during cycle process. The MWCNTs and graphene nanosheets/FeF3 can be acted as catalysts to promote the conversion reaction during the discharge and charge processes. Because of their high specific capacity, low polarizability and good cycle performance, both of these electrodes can be used as potential cathode materials for rechargeable sodium-ion battery, which can provide enough active sites and specific channels to prevent fluorine from dissolving into the electrolyte. Although CF x materials have been proven to be used in rechargeable sodium batteries as cathode materials, the operating mechanism for the electrode material is still unclear. Shao et al. [105] used disordered carbon fiber as a precursor to obtain the fluorinated carbon fiber (CF0.75) in high-temperature fluorine-containing gas and assembled it as a cathode material in a coin-type Na battery. The experimental results showed that the rechargeable Na battery presented a significant initial discharge specific capacity of 705 mA h g−1 and a high rechargeable capacity, and especially its superior first discharge voltage of up to 2.75 V. The measures of theoretical calculations, galvanostatic intermittent titration technique, Soft-XAS and 19F MAS NMR were taken to explore the causes of high voltage and the reversible reaction mechanism during the charge and discharge process of Na batteries. The reversible reaction mechanism of Na/CF0.75 cell is shown in Fig. 14 (a). In the first cycle, sodium ions diffused between the layers of the carbon meta-stable structure and produced NaF. All the fluorine-carbon structures participated in the reaction, resulting in a higher discharge voltage. They proposed that during the charging process, only part of the NaF can be decomposed due to the large polarization voltage and the limitation of the electrolyte application, and the meta-stable structure was not re-formed. Namely, the reversible mechanism of Na/CF0.75 cell can conduct the conversion between of partial-converted CF x with a relatively stable structure and NaF. In order to increase the energy density of sodium ion batteries (SIBs), cathode materials with high theoretical specific capacity and operating voltage need to be developed. However, the large size of Na+ poses problems of bulk expansion and slow kinetics still exist, making it particularly important to stabilize the cathode structure. Due to the strong electronegativity of fluorine, the doping method in cathode materials significantly increases the reversibility of phase transitions and structural stability during charging and discharging cycles [106,107]. It is therefore beneficial to further investigate the mechanism of fluorine doped carbon materials for high capacity of cathode materials. As the most promising electrode materials, carbon materials can provide an abundance of active sites for electrochemical reactions and shorten the diffusion distance of Na+ [108]. The synergistic effect of heteroatom co-doping can increase the interlayer spacing of carbon materials, reduce the volume expansion during charging and discharging processes, and further enhance the electrochemical performance [109]. As the most promising electrode material, carbon materials can also be further enhanced electrochemically through the synergistic effect of heteroatom co-doping. An et al. [110] synthesized fluorine-nitrogen co-doped graphene paper (FNGP) free-standing electrodes as anodes for flexible SIBs by a solvothermal method (Fig. 14b). The F and N co-doping simultaneously increased the structural defects and interlayer distances of graphene, providing abundant active sites, which facilitated the ability to store Na+. The FNGP anodes prepared at 120 °C (FNGP-120) provided a high reversible discharge capacity of 203 mA h g−1 (114.9 mA h cm−3) at a current density of 50 mA g−1 after 100 cycles and a reversible capacity of 56.3 mA h g−1 (31.9 mA h cm−3) at a higher current density of 1 A g−1 after 5000 cycles, exhibiting excellent cycling stability (Fig. 14c and d). Compared with the covalent CF bonds, the ionic CF bond of the FNGP-120 increased the interlayer distance of graphene while maintaining the intrinsic conductivity of graphene, which accelerated the diffusion of sodium ions and electrons. Hence, the prepared anode exhibited excellent capacity and multiplicity performance. Fluorine atoms can also be doped not only into the carbon lattice, but also into the active material of the battery anode to provide a synergistic effect of simultaneous doping. A fluorine-doped NaTi2(PO4)3@C composite (F-NTP@C) with 3D porous structure was also prepared by Deng et al. [111] via a simple sol–gel and high-temperature solid-phase method. The fluorine ions achieved simultaneous doping and formed CF and TiF bonds in the carbon coating and NTP matrix materials, respectively (Fig. 14e and f). The experimental results showed that fluorine ion doping can improve its electronic conductivity and accelerate the migration kinetics of Na+. When the F-NTP@C was used as the anode of the sodium ion battery, both the half battery and the full battery showed excellent performance of sodium ion storage and can operate even in a wide range of temperatures (0–50 °C). The reversible capacity of the sodium ion half battery was 108.7 mA h g−1 at 50 C, and the capacity retention rate was 75.5% after 2000 cycles at 10 C (Fig. 14g and h). In addition, sodium ion full batteries also showed excellent electrochemical reversibility at different current densities. More notably, sodium ion full batteries presented excellent electrochemical performance at different temperatures (Fig. 14i–k), which can meet practical requirements at a wide range of temperatures. 4.2.2 Rechargeable potassium batteries Potassium-based batteries are considered as a promising alternative to Li-based batteries for energy storage systems because of the abundant potassium resources and the similar K+/K potential to Li+/Li. The operating potential and energy density of potassium batteries are expected to be comparable to that of LB and higher than that of sodium-based batteries. Yue et al. [112] prepared a nano carbon fluoride material (NCF0.6) by gas-phase fluorination to report for the first time the use of CF x as a high-capacity conversion cathode for high performance PBs and to explore the mechanism of the reversible conversion reaction. The reaction mechanisms for CF x in a potassium cell are the following equation. (3) F i r s t d i s c h a r g e : C F x + K → K F + C (4) S u b s e q u e n t c y c l e s : C + K F ⇄ CF L + K where CFL denotes the reversible amorphous carbon fluoride phase after the first cycle, which is mainly composed of the semi-ionic CF and CF2 groups. According to Eq. (4), the prepared CF0.6 material can provide a very high theoretical capacity of 687 mA h g−1 when fluorine was fully utilized. The NCF0.6 material provided a reversible capacity of over 250 mA h g−1 at a medium voltage of approximately 2.6 V at 20 mA g−1, demonstrating its great advantage in terms of capacity performance. Despite the discharge capacity decay in the first 50 cycles, the material achieved excellent cycling performance thereafter, achieving a high reversible capacity of ∼95 mA h g−1 at 125 mA g−1 and maintaining it for 900 cycles. The excellent performance was possibly due to the accumulation of KF on the surface generated during cycling, resulting in increasing internal resistance until it was completely covered, which still needed to be further explored. The work suggested the feasibility of CF x materials as conversion cathodes for potassium batteries and provided a promising new avenue for realizing the use of CF x materials in rechargeable battery systems. In addition to the structural design of carbon source and the adjustment of fluorination path to improve the performance of CF x , the battery rechargeability can be obtained by adjusting the CF bond strength of CF x through alkaline ions. Chen et al. [113]. inserted weakly electronegative K+ into fluorinated soft carbon with large CC layers to modulate the strength of the CF bonds, forming the ternary phase K x FC, and the ternary relative CF x reversibility of the CF structure was very important. However, the implementation of this reversible reaction in carbonaceous materials with small layer spacing and less defects such as graphene and carbon nanotubes is still rather difficult. Carbonaceous materials are widely used in potassium ion batteries (PIBs) anodes due to their large layer spacing, excellent chemical stability and abundance of active sites [114]. Due to the large radius of the potassium ion, huge volume expansion and kinetic hysteresis due to repeated insertion/extraction of K+ can occur in potassium-based batteries, limiting the K+ storage performance and restricting its application to some extent. The heteroatom doping not only creates structural defects and active sites for K+ adsorption in carbonaceous materials, but also increases the interlayer spacing to facilitate the insertion/extraction of K+ during cycling [115]. Liu et al. [116] obtained an N, F co-doped fluorine-doped ultra-thin nitrogen-rich carbon nanosheet (CPTHB-F) by carbonizing a rigid polymer porous framework (PTHB) and polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) as the N and F sources for use as the anodes in KIBs (Fig. 15 a). The tested results and Bragg’s law calculations showed that the CPTHB-F had more structural defects caused by F doping to provide more sites for K ion storage. And the interlayer distances of CPTHB and CPTHB-F were 3.2 and 3.5 Å, respectively, indicating that the F-doping enlarged the interlayer distance of the carbon layers, which facilitated the rapid intercalation/deintercalation of K+. Therefore, the F-doped ultrathin carbon nanosheet material had excellent discharge capacity stability and rate performance. The CPTHB-F electrode obtained an excellent long-term reversible capacity of 137.3 mA h g−1 after 690 cycles at a current density of 0.5 A g−1 and the KIBs assembled with CPTHB-F anodes exhibited a high specific capacity of 115.3 mA h g−1 at a high rate of 5.0 A g−1 (Fig. 15b and c). Wu et al. [117] used wet milling combined with high temperature thermal reduction of mixed PVDF and graphene oxide (GO) to form the composite (CF@rGO) of porous fluorocarbon (CF) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as anode materials for KIBs. The increased electron cloud density and layered structure of the CF nanosheets further enhanced the electronic interactions and provided more active sites for K+ embedding during charge and discharge processes. Moreover, the stable CF bond formed facilitated the stabilization of the structure during cycle process and improved cycle stability. The rGO can also provide a conductive network as a substrate to enhance the electronic conductivity for improving the conductivity and capacity of the electrode. Thus, the synergistic interaction between CF and rGO increased the CF@rGO electrode kinetics and improved long cycling stability, exhibiting a reversible capacity of 209.2 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 A g−1 and a high stable capacity of 308.0 mA h g−1 after 1000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1 and maintained a stable structure. Due to the relatively large ionic radius of K+, the insertion/extraction of K+ during cycling can easily lead to the collapse of the electrode structure and rapid loss of capacity, making it particularly important to develop structurally stable electrode materials [118]. Wu et al. [119] proposed a new 3D fluorine-doped carbon covered Ti3C2 composite anode material (3D FC@Ti3C2) for KIBs (Fig. 15d). In the composite electrode material, the prepared fluorine-doped carbon can provide more defects and introduce a large number of active sites which can strongly adsorb K+. In addition, the enlarged layer spacing and 3D interconnected carbon framework improved the electrical conductivity and mitigated the volume expansion during K+ insertion/extraction. At the same time, the obtained Ti3C2 encapsulated by fluorine-doped carbon avoided being oxidized and self-stacking. As a result of these synergistic effects, the formed 3D FC@Ti3C2 achieved the exceptional electrochemical performance with a high capacity of up to 288 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 100 mA g−1 and a reversible capacity of 174 mA h g−1 was also retained after 1000 stable cycles at 500 mA g−1 (Fig. 15e and f). After 200 cycles at 100 mA h g−1, the SEM image in Fig. 15(g) shows that the 3D FC@Ti3C2 composite electrode structure still retains the shape of the sheet/3D interconnect, indicating that excellent structural stability is maintained due to the fluorine doping and carbon coverage. 4.2.3 Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries Compared to sodium ions (1.02 Å) and potassium ions (1.38 Å), lithium ions (0.76 Å) have a smaller ionic radius, which results in higher reaction kinetics at the electrode. Moreover, lithium-ion batteries have the lowest redox potential (−3.04Li+/Li vs. E 0) when compared to sodium ion batteries (−2.71Na+/Na vs. E 0) and potassium ion batteries (−2.93 K+/K vs. E 0). All of these merits suggests that high operating potential and outstanding energy density can be obtained for lithium ions cells. In the face of a deteriorating environment and global warming, there is a more urgent need for sustainable energy storage technologies. Owing to their high energy density and long cycle stability, lithium batteries are considered to be the most promising energy storage devices and have been successfully used to power electric vehicles and electronic portable devices. CF x is a promising electrode material for lithium batteries due to the combined lithium storage mechanism of fluorine and carbon with lithium ions, i.e., (C x F) n + nLi++ne−→xnC + nLiF and C6 + xLi++xe−→Li x C. Some studies have also shown that CF x storage of lithium in the voltage range of 0.01–3.00 V is feasible. Jayasinghe et al. [68] prepared fully fluorinated and mildly fluorinated CF x cell electrodes using multi-walled carbon nanotubes as the carbon source. The mildly fluorinated multi-walled carbon nanotubes exhibited high capacity and admirable stability when used as anodes against Li, showing a reversible capacity of 429 mA h g−1 after 30 cycles. As everyone knows, graphene possesses excellent conductivity, high surface area and chemical stability, making it a potential candidate for lithium storage anode materials. Through introducing fluorine atoms, the adsorption sites and Li+ diffusion capacity of graphene can be increased. The obtained results can enhance reversible capacity for lithium storage when compared to pristine graphene, making fluorination an effective strategy for improving Li-ion battery anodes. Zhan et al. [120] prepared self-supported F-graphene nanosheets on a large scale by a simple liquid exfoliation method. The prepared F-graphene nanosheets had a high fluorine content and a 2D structure, which provided abundant fluorine active sites for lithium storage and facilitated the rapid diffusion of lithium ions during charging and discharging processes. The results showed that at a high current density of 500 mA g−1, the reversible capacity of the F-graphene nanosheets was 336 mA h g−1 and when the rate returned to the initial 50 mA g−1, and the cell showed very good reversibility and still maintained a reversible capacity of 780 mA h g−1. In order to reduce costs and increase CF x production efficiency to meet the demands of commercialization, Jeon et al. [121]. prepared the first edge-fluorinated graphene nanosheets (FGnPs) by introducing fluorine into the edges of GnPs through a simple and efficient ball milling process and investigated their energy storage performance as anode for Li-ion batteries (Fig. 16 a). The SEM images in Fig. 16(b and c) shows a significant reduction in the particle size of FGnPs after ball milling, which means that the unchaining of graphite C–C bonds has produced active carbon species and reacted with fluorine gas to form CF bonds at the edges. The prepared FGnPs had an initial discharge specific capacity of 1778.1 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C and a charging capacity of 1176.3 mA h g−1 with a high initial Coulomb efficiency (66.2%). More strikingly, the prepared FGnPs electrode had an initial charge capacity of up to 650.3 mA h g−1 at 0.5 C in the voltage range of 0.02–3.00 V, which was higher than that of conventional graphite-based electrodes (Fig. 16d). The FGnPs electrodes exhibited excellent cycling stability with 76.6% capacity remaining after 500 cycles, which can be attributed to the dense SEI layer formed during the first cycle. In addition to the higher electronegativity of fluorine at the edges of the FGnPs resulting in a net positive charge on the adjacent carbon atoms, the F-doping can also facilitate the extraction/insertion of Li+ from the electrodes during cycling. The F-doping not only facilitates the extraction/insertion of Li+ from the electrode, but also increases the active sites which is an effective way to enhance the electrochemical activity and stability of graphene in the field of energy storage. However, in conventional lithiation of fluorine-doped graphene, the electrochemically active CF groups are inevitably converted to conductive carbon and then embedded in LiF crystals, affecting the effect of F doping. For example, An et al. [122] obtained F-doped reduced graphene oxide (F-rGO) mainly doped with electrochemically inert CF2 groups in a one-step solvothermal process using rGO as a precursor and hydrofluoric acid (HF) as a fluorine source for the anode materials of lithium-ion battery (Fig. 16e and f). The formation of electrochemically inert CF2 groups with high dissociation energy expanded the interlayer distance and formed vacant sites in the graphene framework which can be acted as active sites for additional Li+ storage to enhance the adsorption energy and lower the Li+ embedding barrier as shown in the Fig. 16(g). The atomic distribution of F-rGO (Fig. 16h) shows that the fluorine atoms are uniformly distributed in the graphene, indicating an effective fluorine doping of rGO can be realized. When used as an anode of Li-ion batteries, the defects and vacancies created by the F-rGO allowed for an increase in specific capacity, which reached 1690 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at a current density of 100 mA g−1 and showed the stable cycling (Fig. 16i), indicating that it is necessary to fully exploit the advantages of CF x in battery electrodes by adjusting the nature of the CF bond. Based on the XPS and DFT calculations, He et al. [123] concluded that the storage mechanism of lithium in fluorinated graphdiyne (F-GDY) was a reversible transformation of the CF bond from semi-ionic to ionic bonding during charging and discharging processes, resulting in stable electrochemical stability properties. The storage mechanism of lithium in F-GDY was shown in the Fig. 16(j). Based on tests and calculations, it was concluded that lithium atoms can be mainly stored in position I of F-GDY, which was near the CF semi-ionic and C(sp)–C(sp) bonds. In addition, lithium atoms can be adsorbed in position II of 6-C. During discharge processes, the semi-ionic CF bond can be transformed into an ionic CF bond and the Li+ was bonded to the F ion by the electrostatic interaction. During charging processes, the Li+ were de-inserted from the F-GDY framework and the F− re-form semi-ionic CF bonds with the carbon atoms. The highly reversible reaction not only provided an abundance of active sites for lithium storage increasing the energy density, but also ensured good cycling performance. A cathodic peak at 0.76 V is observed in the CV curve in Fig. 16(k), which implies the formation of a new chemical structure. It was shown that after 9000 cycles at a current density of 2 A g−1, a stable specific discharge capacity of approximately 350 mA h g−1 was still available representing 70% of the initial specific discharge capacity (Fig. 16l). During the electrochemical reaction, CF x will react with lithium to form LiF, which is a key component of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) in rechargeable lithium batteries and can effectively improve interfacial stability. Shen et al. [124] prepared a GF-LiF-Li composite anode (Fig. 17 a) by reacting GF with Li to produce LiF. The corresponding DFT calculation was used to show the spontaneous reduction of fluorinated graphene to LiF and graphene upon contact with lithium metal. The composite electrode can be stabilized for long periods in ambient air due to the hydrophobic GF-LiF layer and effectively stabilized the interface of the working anode (Fig. 17b). The constant current charge and discharge cycles also had demonstrated that the GF-LiF-Li composite anode can still achieve a specific capacity of almost 140 mA h g−1 after 12 and 24 h of exposure to air. In contrast, Li anodes without the GF-LiF layer exhibited poor cycling stability after 12 h of exposure to air, and after 24 h of exposure to air, the Li metal was directly corroded to the extent which it did not provide discharge capacity (Fig. 17c). In addition, Cui et al. [125] made the surface of the mesophase carbon microspheres (MCMB) highly fluorinated while the internal graphite structure remained unchanged through fluorination control, and then formed a uniform LiF-rich SEI in situ on the MCMB surface to prevent the vertical growth of Li dendrites. Xia et al. [126] prepared fluorinated carbon fibers (FCF) by a simple one-step fluorination strategy and used them as lithium metal 3D scaffold hosts to avoid volume changes during charging and discharging processes and to form stable SEIs. The robust LiF-rich SEIs formed by FCF and molten lithium were very thin and homogeneous, which can effectively regulate homogeneous lithium nucleation and growth. Thanks to the fast charge transfer capability of the FCF host and the stable SEI layer, the assembled cells with the FCF hosted Li can provide excellent electrochemical performance. Furthermore, some carbon-based collectors are considered to be the most attractive materials for Li metal hosts. Surface morphology modulation and functionalization are the keys to effectively suppressing the inhomogeneous deposition of lithium dendrites. Fluorine-doped carbon materials can not only form LiF, but also contain fluorine functional groups which can also fully exploit the activity of fluorine atoms. Xiao et al. [127] prepared nitrogen-doped step-like carbon nanosheets (N-SCS) with abundant edge sites by a modified molten salt synthesis method. Then, the ultra-high fluorine 2D stepped carbon nanosheets (F10N-SCS) were prepared by C4F8 plasma treatment of N-SCS as shown in Fig. 17(d). The edge surface of the stepped nanostructure will help to fully expand the electrochemically active sites and improve the mass transfer properties of Li+. In addition, the successful introduction of elemental F onto the surface of the stepped carbon nanosheets also allowed the formation of LiF-rich SEI to further improve the stability of the Li metal anode. According to experimental results and theoretical simulations, the synergistic effect of the abundant edge sites and the fluorine-rich active interface promoted the homogeneous lithium nucleation in the initial stages of Li plating and the formation of a robust LiF-rich SEI layer. The prepared F10N-SCS can be acted as a stable Li metal anode and it can also easily achieve step-edge guided nucleation and growth processes as well as dendrite free, excellent lithium plating/exfoliation behavior. Therefore, the Li@F10N-SCS|Li symmetric cell can be stably cycled for 3000 h at 1 mA cm−2. In addition, the full cell assembled with the Li-plated F10N-SCS anode and LFP cathode had excellent cycling stability and rate performance, and the Li@F10N-SCS|LFP cell still had a capacity retention of 98.8% after 150 cycles, demonstrating its potential for practical applications (Fig. 17e and f). CF x materials not only form a stable SEI layer on lithium metal, but also interact with the electrode material to achieve good compatibility for improving cycling stability. Lim et al. [49] designed and prepared a bifunctional CF x coated separator which utilized the LiF formed after the first discharge to form a stable SEI layer on the lithium metal. While the CF x coated side towards the cathode can capture the cobalt ions dissolved from the LiCoO2 (LCO) cathode to avoid the migration of cobalt ions to the lithium anode to be reduced to cobalt metal. And its direct coating on the cathode material can also form covalent CF bonds to achieve electrochemical storage and high energy density release by exerting the synergistic effect of carbon coating and F-doping to improve the electrons and ions transportations of the cathode materials. The fluorine-doped carbon (FC) was synthesized by Wang et al. [128] using PVDF as the fluorine and carbon source and coated on the surface of LiFePO4 (LFP) to prepare LFP@FC nanocomposites, which tightly covered the surface of LFP to construct a “core–shell” 3D conductive network, facilitating the transfer of electrons during the cycling process and shortening the diffusion distance of Li+. The defects caused by the highly electronegative F doping improved the electrochemical reactivity of LFP, and in particular the composite (LFP@FC-II) containing about 2.8 wt% FC modification achieved a high capacity close to the theoretical value with excellent rate performance and long cycling capability. The initial discharge capacity of LFP@FC-II reached 122.6 mA h g−1 at 10 C, and the reversible capacity remained 86.6% after 1000 cycles. In addition, Zheng et al. [129] also synthesized fluorine-doped carbon surface modified Li1.2Mn0.54Ni0.13Co0.13O2 (LMCNO@C-F) cathode materials using PVDF as the fluorine source by the sol–gel method and investigated the effect of fluorine doping on the electrochemical performance of lithium-ion batteries in detail. The nanoscale fluorine doped carbon surfaces can increase the electronic conductivity of composite electrodes and inhibit the dissolution of manganese metal ions and huge volume change, thus stabilizing the electrode structure. Besides, the strong electronic coupling and formation of Mn–F bonds between the F-doped carbon layer and the bulk material can also effectively suppress the side reactions between the electrode and the electrolyte. The results showed that the LMCNO@C-F exhibited an initial Coulomb efficiency of up to 82.4% and had excellent rate performance and cycle stability, especially a capacity retention rate of 88.5% can be achieved after 500 cycles at 5 C. As the field of application of Li-ion batteries expands, the demand for their energy density becomes more demanding. Among these, Ni-rich layered oxides are considered to be competitive cathode materials. Qiu et al. [130]. demonstrated that the proper introduction of fluorine in the LiNi0.9Co0.05Mn0.05O2 (NCM955) cathode can stabilize the crystal structure, improve the Li+ transport kinetics and significantly improve the overall electrochemical performance. Therefore, F-doped carbon materials in nickel-rich cathode materials are still worthy of further investigation by researchers to meet the growing demand for high-energy Li-ion batteries. In recent years, many efforts have been conducted to improve the electrical conductivity of anode materials and to prevent volume expansion during charging and discharging processes, with fluorine-doped carbon material modification being an effective strategy. Similarly, thanks to the high electronic conductivity of the CF x layer and its ability to ensure rapid ion diffusion, CF x can still be used as a composite material for the anode of lithium-ion batteries to improve the electrochemical performance of overall the electrode. Ming et al. [22] prepared Fe3O4@CF x composite material as the anode of lithium-ion battery by a one-step method to coating Fe2O3 nanoparticles with a layer of CF x and matched with LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 cathode to assemble a Li-ion full cell. The cell had a high energy density of 371 W h kg−1 (vs. cathode) at a current density of 100 mA g−1 and can be cycled for more than 300 cycles with a capacity retention of 66.8%. Even at 45 °C, it still exhibited a high energy density of 316 W h kg−1 (vs cathode) and a high capacity of 91.6 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1. Optimization of the electrode structure is of great importance for ion diffusion and electron transport. Liang et al. [131] designed and prepared a 3D hierarchical heterostructure (MoSe2/NFC) of ultrathin nanosheet MoSe2 assembled with F, N co-doped carbon (Fig. 17g–i) to improve the lithium storage capacity. The F, N co-doped carbon can improve the electrical conductivity and promote the diffusion ability of lithium ions while suppressing the volume change of MoSe2 during the insertion/extraction of lithium ions. Thanks to these advantages, the prepared 3D MoSe2/NFC composites exhibited the improved rate performance and ultra-long cycling capabilities, reaching higher discharge capacities of 853.9, 782.1, 713.2, 663.2, 621.2, 563 and 452.9 mA h g−1 at 0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 A g−1, respectively. Moreover, the MoSe2/NFC composite electrode material still had a high capacity of 838.9 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.1 A g−1 and even had a high capacity retention of 98.3% after 1000 cycles at a high current density of 2 A g−1 (Fig. 17j and k). It further demonstrated that the F, N co-doped carbon can avoid huge volume change and prevent agglomeration and pulverization of the MoSe2 nanosheets during charging and discharging processes. 4.2.4 Rechargeable lithium-sulfur batteries Elemental sulfur has the advantage of being low-cost, abundant and sustainable. Its application in combination with lithium metal to form a battery system is widely used and has received a great deal of attention from many researchers. With a higher theoretical energy density (2600 W h kg−1) and theoretical specific capacity (1673 mA h g−1) than those of the prevalent lithium-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur batteries are one of the most attractive candidates to meet the next generation of energy storage requirements [132]. However, in practical applications lithium-sulfur batteries still face significant challenges due to the large volume expansion (∼80%) during lithiation/de-lithiation, slow kinetic reaction problems and the LiPSs (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) shuttle. To address these issues, a large number of efforts have been conducted in recent years to develop cathode material host matrices or to introduce appropriate LiPSs barrier layers to improve the sulfur loading and utilization [133,134]. Because of the unique advantages of nanostructured carbonaceous materials such as high electrical conductivity, excellent workability and scalable productivity, compounding them with sulfur is one of the most widely adopted methods. However, most inactive carbonaceous bodies lower the energy density of the actual cell to some extent and lack active sites where LiPSs can be adsorbed through chemical interactions, which inevitably leads to the capacity decay with cycling. Chemical modification of carbon materials by halogen doping has been proven to be an effective strategy for suppressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs in Li-S batteries. Olanrele et al. [135]. revealed the strong interactions between halogenated graphene and LiPSs through first-principles calculations. The binding energy induced by the halogenated dopant can not only effectively traps the LiPSs, but also significantly accelerate the reaction kinetics of the Li-S battery. The element fluorine, as the halogen atom with the strongest electronegativity, can effectively enhance the dipole moment, allowing the fluorinated nanostructured carbon to interact with soluble LiPSs and suppress their shuttle effect. Wang et al. [136] designed and prepared an asymmetric self-supporting hybrid carbon nanotube sponge composite electrode (F-CNTs@CSP), where the porous and conductive CSP can be acted as an ideal reservoir for sufficient sulfur loading to provide sufficient space for electrons transfer and ions diffusion (Fig. 18 a). A layer of deeply fluorinated carbon nanotubes (FCNTs, F/C ratio of 0.88) with a thickness of 0.5 µm was covered on one side. The F-CNT layer had a strong affinity for soluble LiPSs and can effectively prevent the diffusion of soluble LiPSs out of the CSP and was verified by first principles calculations (Fig. 18b–e). The calculations showed that the F-CNT greatly enhanced the binding to soluble LiPSs due to the strong electron-absorbing ability of the F atom, thus inhibiting the diffusion of LiPSs from the cathode to the anode. Therefore, F-CNTs@CSP electrode achieved a specific capacity of 1344 mA h g−1 at a sulfur loading of 2.55 mg cm−2 and a current density of 0.2 C, accompanied by a capacity retention rate of 85.27% after 100 cycles. Furthermore, the specific capacity of 868.9 mA h g−1 was maintained after 100 cycles at 0.1 C with a high sulfur loading of 5.10 mg cm−2 (Fig. 18f and g). The fluorine-doped porous hollow carbon nanospheres (FPHCs) with controllable particle size were synthesized by Hu et al. [137] through a simple one-step gas–solid interface reaction using silica or silica spheres as sacrificial templates and Teflon as carbon and fluorine sources (Fig. 18h–l). The prepared FPHCs had a maximum pore volume of 7.16 cm3 g−1 (Fig. 18m) for high sulfur loading and the F-doping can enhance the adsorption and interaction between fluorine-doped carbon and LiPSs, resulting in excellent rate performance and stable cycling in Li-S cells with high sulfur content. Thus, the Li-S cells assembled with the S@FPHCs cathodes having high sulfur content (88 wt%) and loading (3.5 mg cm−2) achieved a stable reversible capacity of 531 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 2 C with a low capacity decay of only 0.054% per cycle and a high coulombic efficiency close to 100% (Fig. 18n). In another work, they also synthesized the N/F double-doped hollow micro/mesoporous carbon nanospheres (NFHCs) as the host of sulfur carriers by a one-step in situ reaction method, taking advantage of the chemisorption/catalytic ability of the N/F active center and the hollow porous structure to achieve strong anchoring and rapid conversion of LiPSs [138]. Compared to single atom doping, double doping can provide stronger chemisorption and conversion for LiPSs due to synergistic effects to suppress their shuttle effect. Xiao et al. [139] introduced both transition metal and fluorine co-doped carbon materials (MoSe2@FC@Mo2C) into Li-S battery cathode materials to exploit their synergistic effects to achieve effective and stable electrochemical performance. The prepared MoSe2@FC@Mo2C had stepwise multi-electrocatalysis, selectively catalyzing the conversion of short-chain (Li2S4 ↔ Li2S) soluble LiPSs via the polar FC and long-chain LiPSs (S8 ↔ Li2S4) via the MoSe2 and Mo2C. Finally, the prepared MoSe2@FC@Mo2C/S achieved a capacity of 1359 mA h g−1 at a high sulfur loading of 5.5 mg cm−2 and a high current density of 2 C and was able to cycle stably for more than 1000 cycles, corresponding to a capacity decay of only 0.029% per cycle. The work also provided a strong indication of the effect of fluorine-doped carbon materials on the mitigation of LiPSs shuttling and conversion capabilities, offering a new approach to the catalytic conversion of LiPSs. In addition, Kang’s group prepared a series of metal fluoride and fluorine doped porous carbon nanofibers (PCNF) by a one-step carbonization process using PTFE as the fluorine source to enhance the electrical conductivity of the electrode and to form a fluorinated interface for the physical and chemical adsorption of LiPSs using its synergistic effect [25,27,28,31]. To prepare this bifunctional fluorinated carbon material, they also grew YF3 on the outside of semi-hermetic fluorine-doped PCNFs by carbonization treatment to form semi-closed YF3-doped 1D carbon nanofibers with a 3D porous network. The electrode materials can ensure excellent external conductivity and fast Li+ transport, providing a second physical and chemical barrier to the diffusion of polysulfides [25]. To further increase the sulfur loading, they also constructed new bionic porous carbon matrices with a hierarchical structure. The LaF3-doped pomegranate-like fluorine-doped PCNF structure imparted the continuous and fast electron transport capability for the composite electrode, and the hierarchical structure also allowed for the multi-stage and strong physical adsorption of LiPSs during the discharge process. More importantly, the porous carbon skeleton improved by active ionic/semi-ionic C–F and LaF3 nanocrystals can form a rich polar interface with strong chemical interactions for LiPSs [28]. In addition, they have embedded both CoF3 and YF3 nanoparticles into the fluorine-doped PCNF [31]. The formation of ionic/semi-ionic C–F and the combined effect of the bimetallic nanoparticles can also provide an abundance of active sites that accelerate the kinetics of the sulfur redox reaction and allow for the physical and chemical adsorption of LiPSs. As a result, the composite cathode exhibits a discharge specific capacity of 1038 mA h g−1 at a sulfur loading of 2.1 mg cm−2 and can be stably cycled for 1000 cycles. These novel efforts offer promising strategies for the development of high-performance Li-S battery cathode materials. The fluorine-doped carbon materials for Li-S batteries are also essentially a way to protect the cell cathode. Alternatively, the introduction of a CF x material interlayer between the cathode and separator is an effective strategy to both inhibit dissolution and shuttling of LiPSs and to improve the rate performance of Li-S battery [140]. Li et al. [141] explored a interlayer material of F-MWCNTs composite with cellulose fibers for use between cathode and separator to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. The surface defects of MWCNTs caused by fluorination can provide a convenient pathway for Li+ transport to diffuse and obtained the electrochemically active C–F sites, which can significantly improve the electrical conductivity and adsorption of LiPSs, greatly avoiding their dissolution and diffusion during cycling. Thanks to the synergistic effect of F-MWCNTs and cellulose fibers, the obtained F-MWCNTs interlayer Li-S battery was possible to achieve an initial discharge capacity of 1055 mA h g−1 at a current density of 1 C and a stable cycle of 200 cycles. The soluble LiPSs formed on the cathode side can diffuse to the anode side through the notorious shuttle effect and be reduced to the inactive Li2S2/Li2S, resulting in a loss of active materials. The low Coulomb efficiency and the growth of irregular Li dendrites are the main hindrances to the development of Li-S batteries [142]. Kang’s group had also done some works on fluorine-doped anode-side interlayers for batteries, investigating their protective effect on Li metal and their barrier effect on LiPSs [24,29,30,32]. Considering the strong polarity of elemental F and fluorine compounds, they introduced fluorine into the 3D PCNF to form a CF bond and metal fluoride (ZnF2), which can be seen from the TEM images, EDS mapping and XPS spectra in Fig. 19 (a–f), and then coated it on the side of the commercial separator as a functional layer between the anode and the separator [29]. The ZnF2-PCNFs can inhibit both physically and chemically the growth of Li dendrites and physically trapped and chemisorbed LiPSs through increasing active sites and network structures of the PCNF (Fig. 19g). As a result, the assembled Li-S battery had excellent rate recovery performance and cycling stability, with an initial capacity of 829.50 mA h g−1 at 1 C and a capacity retention of 65.28% after 500 cycles (Fig. 19h). They also prepared a fluorine-doped PAN based CNF and used it as a functional layer between the separator and the anode to inhibit Li dendrite growth, increase interfacial compatibility and anchor the LiPSs during cycle processes [32]. The fluorine doping provided an abundance of electrochemical sites and greatly enhanced interfacial interactions through chemical mechanism of action, inducing homogeneous Li deposition. In addition, the CNF network structure can also accommodate the large volume expansion of sulfur electrode and suppress their shuttle effects. Combining with the synergistic effect of the network structure, the interaction between F-doped carbon nanofibers and LiPSs can be seen in the Fig. 19(i), where the Li2S6 solution becomes clearer after the addition of F-doped PAN-based carbon nanofibers compared to pure PAN-based carbon nanofibers. Thanks to these advantages, the Li-S batteries assembled with the modified separator of YF3-PAN-1 exhibited excellent rate and cycling performance, with a first discharge specific capacity of 1165.8 mA h g−1 and maintaining a discharge specific capacity of 740.5 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 19j). 5 Conclusions and outlook Carbon-based materials are widely used in battery systems because of their abundant sources, low cost and good stability. In particular, nanostructured carbon-based materials rich in large specific surface area can provide shortened paths for the diffusion and transportation of ions and electrons, improving the performance of the battery. Since the electronegativity of fluorine and carbon atoms is extremely different, doping carbon materials can generate more crystal defect sites inside the interlayer of carbon structure, add more reactive sites in electrochemical reactions, improve the network structure and increase the diffusion efficiency of electrons and ions in cell electrodes. CF x electrode materials are of interest because they have the highest specific energy density of all lithium primary batteries. For the time being, the energy density of fluorinated carbon is high, mainly in terms of high discharge capacity. In fact, the average discharge potential is significantly lower than that of the theoretical electrochemical potential of a pure ionic CF bond. Due to the poor electrical conductivity of the strongly covalent CF bond, the corresponding battery can only achieve a moderate range of discharge currents. Moreover, the CF2 and CF3 groups are electrochemically inert and can even hinder the diffusion of lithium or fluorine, thus reducing the electrochemical kinetics during the charge–discharge processes. Therefore, to overcome the challenges posed by the relationship between fluorine content and power density, researchers should work on new approaches to develop CF x materials with high fluorine content but maintaining good electrical conductivity, which could focus strategies on fluorination techniques and structural design of carbon sources which allow a trade-off between energy and power density. All in all, in this view, we also outline some methods of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials depending on the fluorine source and delve into the mechanism of action of them in battery systems. Finally, the current status of the application of different fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials in primary and secondary batteries are also summarized. Systematically, the main focus is on the fluorine doping and modification of electrode materials and interlayer materials, with the aim of attracting researchers to pay more attention to the excellent properties of fluorine-doped nanocarbon materials and to apply them in more types of energy storage devices to meet the growing demand for energy storage. The outlook is shown in Fig. 20 . In the course of our review, we find that the functionality of fluorine doping in carbonaceous materials for battery systems is promising and still worth exploring in many respects. (1) The pathways formed by CF x materials in the cell are critical to electrochemical kinetics and multi-dimensional composite CF x material structures should be constructed to increase multi-directional ion diffusion and electron transfer pathways and shorten transport distances. The active sites in CF x materials can physically, chemically or their combined interact with LiPSs, thereby reducing the shuttling of LiPSs. However, when all active sites are adsorbed by LiPSs and there is not enough space for more formed LiPSs, the inhibitory effect of the F-doped carbon materials may diminish or even disappear. Therefore, in order to effectively improve the inhibition of LiPSs by F-doped carbon materials, the material properties can be improved by increasing the number of active sites or enhancing their adsorption capacities. In addition, multi-stage pore structures and the introduction of other functional groups can also be constructed to improve their adsorption effect on LiPSs, thus achieving superior inhibitory effects. (2) The development of in-situ characterization techniques is particularly important in current materials preparation and applications to understand the relationship between the structures and properties of CF x materials. Faced with the limited basic research on the ion reaction mechanism during the insertion/de-insertion of CF x materials, there is a need to trace the charge/discharge reaction mechanisms and phase transition processes of CF x materials using tools such as in-situ projection electron microscopy and XRD tests. Additionally, XPS, AFM, Raman, and X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) can also be employed for the detection of CF x for better controlling the formation of corresponding structures, thereby saving costs and achieving efficient production. (3) Much work has been done on the synergistic effects of co-doping F atoms with other heteroatoms or fluorides, and the effect of their hybridization on electrochemical properties should be further clarified. (4) To meet the demand for high performance energy storage batteries, many high-voltage cathodes have been developed to provide high energy density. However, the rate performance and cycling stability of the battery at high-voltage still needs to be enhanced. The reversibility and structural stability of fluorine-doped carbon materials for cathode materials deserve further investigation to reduce the volume expansion of ions during insertion/de-insertion processes and to avoid the loss of active materials. (5) LiF is the discharge product of the primary battery and the main component of the SEI protective layer of the secondary battery. However, the formation of excessively thick LiF can increase the internal resistance and reduce the battery capacity. Therefore, regulating the formation of LiF is not only an opportunity, but also a challenge to improve the battery performance. (6) As one of the mainstream directions for electrochemical energy storage devices, flexible devices still present significant challenges in terms of application. Research on self-supporting flexible CF x electrodes is expected to lead to the popularization of wearable electronics. Therefore, CF x have a broad prospect and potential for development. As is well known, fluorine is a key element of various components in different batteries. Not only fluorinated/fluorine-doped carbon materials play an important role in various battery system, but also other fluorinated materials such as Li-ion salts electrolyte with some fluorinated ions, electrode binders based on fluorinated polymers and metal fluorides as active materials for electrode oxidation–reduction reactions have also made remarkable achievements in previous researches, making significant contributions to their electrochemical performances. For example, F-based inorganic or organic compounds in liquid electrolytes usually have more stable oxidation resistance and can effectively improve cathode performance by forming a stable cathode electrolyte interfaces, and the high ionicity of the M−F bonds in metal fluorides usually favors higher reaction voltages. The review focuses on the function mechanisms and application progresses of fluorinated/fluorine-doped carbon materials in various batteries. Her research mainly concentrates on electrospun nanomaterials, including fluoride, oxide and polymer nanofibers for lithium metal batteries Nanping Deng obtained his Ph.D. in Textile Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2018. Now, he is working in School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, China. Dr. Deng mainly focuses on the preparation, modification and molding mechanism of nanomaterials, including F-doped porous carbon nanofibers and metal fluorides for batteries and electrocatalytic applications. Gang Wang received his Master’s degree in Materials Science and Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2020. He is now pursuing his Ph.D. there. His current research interests focus on the electrocatalytic process of 1D carbon-based nanomaterials. Ruru Yu received her bachelor’s degree in Nonwoven Engineering, Tiangong University, China, in 2023. She mainly concentrates on the preparation of electrospun inorganic nanofibers and their application in lithium metal batteries. Xiaoxiao Wang received his Ph.D. in Textile Science and Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2022. His research interests concentrate on the design of functional nanofibers and the construction of nanofiber aerogels, and their application in the field of energy storage. Bowen Cheng received his doctoral degree in Chemical Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2003, and studied in Hochschule Niederrhein, Germany as a doctoral exchange student in 2001. Then he was appointed as a research associate at the University of Leeds, England. He is currently a professor in Tiangong University. His research focuses on novel fiber materials, advanced functional nonwovens and smart textiles for energy harvesting and storage. Jingge Ju obtained her Ph.D. in Textile Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2019. Now, she is working in School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, China. Her research interests concentrate on the preparation, modification and forming mechanisms of novel nanofiber materials and their applications in energy and the environment. Weimin Kang has been working in Tiangong University, China since 2007, and obtained his doctoral degree in textile chemical engineering from Tiangong University in 2012. He was appointed to professor in 2017. His scientific interests are the design, preparation, and evaluation of energy materials and their application in the fields of catalysis, energy harvesting and storage.

coredata.dc:description: With the popularity and widespread applications of electronics, higher demands are being placed on the performance of battery materials. Due to the large difference in electronegativity between fluorine and carbon atoms, doping fluorine atoms in nanocarbon-based materials is considered an effective way to improve the performance of used battery. However, there is still a blank in the systematic review of the mechanism and research progress of fluorine-doped nanostructured carbon materials in various batteries. In this review, the synthetic routes of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based (CF x ) materials under different fluorine sources and the function mechanism of CF x in various batteries are reviewed in detail. Subsequently, judging from the dependence between the structure and electrochemical performance of nanocarbon sources, the progress of CF x based on different dimensions (0D–3D) for primary battery applications is reviewed and the balance between energy density and power density is critically discussed. In addition, the roles of CF x materials in secondary batteries and their current applications in recent years are summarized in detail to illustrate the effect of introducing F atoms. Finally, we envisage the prospect of CF x materials and offer some insights and recommendations to facilitate the further exploration of CF x materials for various high-performance battery applications.

coredata.dc:title: Fluoridation routes, function mechanism and application of fluorinated/fluorine-doped nanocarbon-based materials for various batteries: A review
